bug.short_desc: gcc9 -fPIC creates unreproducible assembler code

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 827567 test1.c
While working on reproducible builds for openSUSE, I found that our darktables package had multiple unreproducible .o files that resulted in unreproducible .so output.
I used gcc -E $MANYARGS introspection_toneequal.c to produce the attached test1.c reproducer.
Steps to Reproduce: for i in 1 2 ; do gcc-9 -fPIC -S test1.c && md5sum test1.s ; done
Actual Result: produces a different md5sum output for every run.
Expected Result: output should be fully deterministic.
same for gcc

A workaround is to avoind making dt_simd_memcpy and friends 'static'. GCC has to make the ifunc resolver globally visible and has to choose a "unique" name for this purpose. Which is of course hard, so it tries with randomness.

bug.short_desc: openSUSE:Leap:15.2/ltrace failed

long_desc.thetext: openSUSE:Leap:15.2/ltrace failed to build. Please see build log: https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/openSUSE:Leap:15.2/ltrace/standard/x86_64

Hi, from my mail to the opensuse-factory list:
I have a successfully building ltrace for OpenSUSE:Leap:15.2 (see https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:msalle:branches:openSUSE:Leap:15.2/ltrace)
all changes relate to the failing 'make check'. It has a new patch testsuite.patch: - it fixes the warnings from make check - it removes one entry which is using long double which isn't supported by ltrace while the test assumed it did (I actually have a quite extensive patch that enables long double, at least for my 64-bit Leap 15.1).
Plus some small changes to the spec file: - put make check inside a %check - it enforces using en_US.UTF-8 for running the tests, otherwise wchar.exp fails. Another UTF-8 locale should be fine too, but not setting it breaks the tests.
Created attachment 826881 Fix the testsuite warnings during make check

Created attachment 826882 required changes to the spec file
This is not an actual patch for the source itself, but contains the requires changes to the spec file.

attachment.desc: Fix the testsuite warnings during make check
required changes to the spec file

bug.short_desc: GCC 10: grub2 build fails

long_desc.thetext:
Fails due to:
abuild@marxinbox:~/rpmbuild/BUILD/grub-2.04/build-emu/grub-core> gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I../../grub-core -I.. -Wall -W -DGRUB_MACHINE_EMU=1 -DGRUB_MACHINE=X86_64_EMU -I../../include -I../include -DGRUB_FILE=\"disk/mdraid1x_linux.c\" -I. -I../../grub-core -I.. -I../.. -I../../include -I../include -I../../grub-core/lib/libgcrypt-grub/src/ -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -Os -Wall -W -Wshadow -Wpointer-arith -Wundef -Wchar-subscripts -Wcomment -Wdeprecated-declarations -Wdisabled-optimization -Wdiv-by-zero -Wfloat-equal -Wformat-extra-args -Wformat-security -Wformat-y2k -Wimplicit -Wimplicit-function-declaration -Wimplicit-int -Wmain -Wmissing-braces -Wmissing-format-attribute -Wmultichar -Wparentheses -Wreturn-type -Wsequence-point -Wshadow -Wsign-compare -Wswitch -Wtrigraphs -Wunknown-pragmas -Wunused -Wunused-function -Wunused-label -Wunused-parameter -Wunused-value -Wunused-variable -Wwrite-strings -Wnested-externs -Wstrict-prototypes -g -Wredundant-decls -Wmissing-prototypes -Wmissing-declarations -Wextra -Wattributes -Wendif-labels -Winit-self -Wint-to-pointer-cast -Winvalid-pch -Wmissing-field-initializers -Wnonnull -Woverflow -Wvla -Wpointer-to-int-cast -Wstrict-aliasing -Wvariadic-macros -Wvolatile-register-var -Wpointer-sign -Wmissing-include-dirs -Wmissing-prototypes -Wmissing-declarations -Wformat=2 -freg-struct-return -fno-dwarf2-cfi-asm -mno-stack-arg-probe -fno-asynchronous-unwind-tables -fno-unwind-tables -mcmodel=large -fno-PIE -fno-pie -fno-stack-protector -Wtrampolines -Werror -ffreestanding -fno-strict-aliasing -fno-inline-functions-called-once -MT disk/mdraid1x_module-mdraid1x_linux.o -MD -MP -MF disk/.deps-core/mdraid1x_module-mdraid1x_linux.Tpo -c -o disk/mdraid1x_module-mdraid1x_linux.o `test -f 'disk/mdraid1x_linux.c' || echo '../../grub-core/'`disk/mdraid1x_linux.c ../../grub-core/disk/mdraid1x_linux.c: In function 'grub_mdraid_detect': ../../grub-core/disk/mdraid1x_linux.c:181:15: error: array subscript <unknown> is outside array bounds of 'grub_uint16_t[0]' {aka 'short unsigned int[0]'} [-Werror=array-bounds] 181 | (char *) &sb.dev_roles[grub_le_to_cpu32 (sb.dev_number)] | ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ../../grub-core/disk/mdraid1x_linux.c:98:17: note: while referencing 'dev_roles' 98 | grub_uint16_t dev_roles[0]; /* Role in array, or 0xffff for a spare, or 0xfffe for faulty. */ | ^~~~~~~~~ ../../grub-core/disk/mdraid1x_linux.c:127:33: note: defined here 'sb' 127 | struct grub_raid_super_1x sb; | ^~ cc1: all warnings being treated as errors
which is a GCC issue: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=92326

bug.short_desc: LD from binutils 2.33.1 is broken on aarch64

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 824949 tensorflow full build log
While building Tensorflow for Factory:ARM we get the following error:
[20116s] /usr/bin/gcc -shared -o bazel-out/aarch64-opt/bin/tensorflow/python/_pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so '-Wl,-rpath,$ORIGIN/../../_solib_aarch64/_U_S_Stensorflow_Spython_C_Upywrap_Utensorflow_Uinternal.so___Utensorflow' -Lbazel-out/aarch64-opt/bin/_solib_aarch64/_U_S_Stensorflow_Spython_C_Upywrap_Utensorflow_Uinternal.so___Utensorflow -Wl,--version-script bazel-out/aarch64-opt/bin/tensorflow/python/pywrap_tensorflow_internal_versionscript.lds '-Wl,-rpath,$ORIGIN/,-rpath,$ORIGIN/..' -Wl,-soname,_pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so -Wl,-no-as-needed -Wl,-z,relro,-z,now -B/usr/bin -B/usr/bin -pass-exit-codes -Wl,--gc-sections -Wl,@bazel-out/aarch64-opt/bin/tensorflow/python/_pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so-2.params) [20116s] /usr/bin/ld: can not size stub section: invalid operation [20116s] /usr/bin/ld: linker stubs: file class ELFCLASSNONE incompatible with ELFCLASS64 [20116s] /usr/bin/ld: final link failed: file in wrong format [20116s] collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
Building for released Tumbleweed is fine. Major diffs are: * binutils 2.32 > 2.33.1: https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/748099 * kernel 5.3.8 > 5.3.12 * java-1_8_0-openjdk 1.8.0.222 > 1.8.0.232
binutils 2.33 got lots of aarch64 update and the error is from ld, so this is where my suspicions go.

I tried to build this package with an overlay which replaces binutils 2.33.1, by previous version 2.32 and the problem is gone. So, this is really related to binutils 2.33.1 update. Maybe some deps need to be rebuild?

Looks like gcc9 and glibc weren't rebuilt after the binutils update, so I guess thats part of the problem..
I'll trigger a full rebuild, hasn't been done in many months..

Same is happening in rustc:
http://pastebin.nue.suse.com/23631/src

This was a transient error, but I submitted the fix too late to Factory (only now sr#751060). Now we might have the problem that binutils can't build itself anymore on Factory:ARM, in which case someone needs to play games with injecting an working binutils into the tree.

@Michal, thanks for the fix.
For the record, upstream bug is https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25210
I sidestepped the factory review process and linked this fix directly into Factory:ARM. Lets see if we can recover quickly.

Assigning to Micha. Note there is feedback in the upstream bugreport. could you please also add the bugreference to the changes entry?
We were able to recover bootstrap of Factory:ARM with that binutils, thanks a lot!

bug.short_desc: gdb requires fpc for building

long_desc.thetext: gdb requires fpc for building. Unfortunately fpc requires itself so it its not bootstrappable. Means we need yet another aggregates to bring up ring1. Is fpc really needed or could we at least not pull it in when building in staging/rings?

Note this is only for the testsuite, so yes, that's possible. IIRC separating the testsuite to a separate .spec file doesn't help rings? (all .specs from a single source need to reside in the same one?)
second spec could be done but probably not worth the effort in this case. Would make sense if fpc would push gdb too far back in the rebuild path.

There are only six pascal testcases in the gdb testsuite, so it's not so hugely worthwhile. So I could imagine simply not BuildRequiring it in rings is sensible. What was the rpm macro for that, Ludwig?

$ osc meta prjconf openSUSE:Factory:Staging|grep disa # Help us disabled some flavors in mutlibuild packages %_with_ringdisabled 1
so you can use bcond

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-17450: binutils: denial of service in find_abstract_instance in dwarf2.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-17450
find_abstract_instance in dwarf2.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.32, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (infinite recursion and application crash) via a crafted ELF file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-17450 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-17450 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25078

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-17451: binutils: an integer overflow leading to a SEGV in _bfd_dwarf2_find_nearest_line in dwarf2.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-17451
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.32. It is an integer overflow leading to a SEGV in _bfd_dwarf2_find_nearest_line in dwarf2.c, as demonstrated by nm.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-17451 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-17451 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=336bfbeb1848f4b9558456fdcf283ee8a32d7fd1 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25070

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: Intel CPU Jump Conditional Code (JCC) jump misprediction

long_desc.thetext:
(Slide 1) Issue:
Conditional Jumps (JCC) code can have their branch target get corrupted by merging the targets of two branches that happen due to alias within the branch predictor. This occurs when the branch predictor and DSB (Decoded Stream Buffer) get out of sync.
Impact:
Can result in unpredictable system behaviour, typically resulting from jumping to an incorrect location within given process address space and getting a #UD or #PF.
NOTE: impacts SKL-Family products only (no BDW , nor ICL)
Planned workaround:
Disable "CFLB" (Cross Fetch-Line Branch) ability to allocate into the DSB via MCU.
Mitigation included in SKX MCU (0x64) and CLX MCU (0x2b) and respective IPU 2019.2

(Slide 2)
JCC Erratum Workaround Effects
Applications benefitting from the decoded ICache can see degradations from switching to the legacy pipeline.
- workloads with smaller instruction cache footprint can have greater effects
Applications may experience variable performance from build to build
- Will change upon recompile and relink, which changes alignment from branches
Code generators can wrokaround most of the overhead introduced
- Keep branches/macro fused branches from crossing or ending on 32-byte boundaries

Rest of the slides:
https://gitlab.suse.de/security/spec2018/wikis/jcc-slides

Summary:
- MCU mitigates the issue, reduces performance a bit
- Speedups could be gained by adjusting code generation.
Note that for Skylake and Cascade Lake the MCU was already released, version 20190918.

This was published November 11.
https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/support/articles/000055650/processors/intel-xeon-processors.html
https://www.intel.com/content/dam/support/us/en/documents/processors/mitigations-jump-conditional-code-erratum.pdf

Jump Conditional Code Erratum Overview White Paper for Processors
Documentation
Content Type Product Information & Documentation
Article ID 000055650
Last Reviewed 11/08/2019
Starting with the second-generation Intel® Core™ Processors and Intel® Xeon® E3-1200 Series Processors (formerly codenamed Sandy Bridge) and later processor families, the Intel® microarchitecture introduces a microarchitectural structure called the Decoded ICache (also called the Decoded Streaming Buffer or DSB).
The Decoded ICache caches decoded instructions, called micro-ops (μops), coming out of the legacy decode pipeline. The next time the processor accesses the same code, the Decoded ICache provides the μops directly, speeding up program execution.
In some Intel® Processors, there's an erratum (SKX102) that may occur under complex microarchitectural conditions involving jump instructions that span across 64-byte boundaries (cross cache lines). A microcode update (MCU) can prevent this erratum.
For more information about this erratum including how to get the MCU, view the Mitigations for Jump Conditional Code Erratum White Paper.

So basically to summarize:
- the CPU Microcode update fixes the issue, but makes the code a bit slower - the compiler / binutils is supposed to make the code fast again by avoiding conditional jump instructions across 32byte boundaries.

According to the document it's all jumps, not just conditional ones. Microcode updates fix the security issue so this is a request for optimization that should go via Jira?
The document mentions -malign-branch-* and -mbranches-within-32B which neither are available in upstream gas at the very moment (but I guess HJ will commit in a second). Thus a requirement is probably to backport those to 2.32 and update binutils across products.
So far it is not clear if Intel requests this from us for older products. Need to ask Pragyan again.

bug.short_desc: pcc does not build reproducibly with LTO

long_desc.thetext:
/usr/lib64/pcc/x86_64-suse-linux-gnu/1.0.0.RELEASE/lib/*.o differ
e.g. +Contents of section .gnu.lto_.profile.23efe723a460f453: + 0000 789ce360 60044220 0000005d 000b x..``.B ...].. /usr/lib64/pcc/x86_64-suse-linux-gnu/1.0.0.RELEASE/lib/crt0.o differs in ELF section .gnu.lto_.icf.23efe723a460f453
/usr/lib64/pcc/x86_64-suse-linux-gnu/1.0.0.RELEASE/lib/crt0.o: file format elf64-x86-64
+Contents of section .gnu.lto_.icf.23efe723a460f453: + 0000 789ce360 6064e060 40004686 cecf6fba x..``d.`@.F...o. + 0010 1819000e db0306 .......
The .a files are fine, though, because they are stripped by https://github.com/openSUSE/brp-check-suse/blob/master/brp-15-strip-debug#L40

This also affects perl-XML-Parser /usr/share/doc/packages/perl-XML-Parser/Expat/Expat.o maybe that file should not be in there?
also racket /usr/lib64/racket/mzdyn3m.o
and clisp /usr/lib64/clisp-2.49.92/zlib/zlib.o The latter both have other reproducibility issues as well

(In reply to Bernhard Wiedemann from comment #1) > This also affects perl-XML-Parser > /usr/share/doc/packages/perl-XML-Parser/Expat/Expat.o > maybe that file should not be in there?
Good catch! In fact, there are a couple of files that should not be in the doc section. I just submitted a fix here:
https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/725122
Please, let me know if that fixes the LTO build in ppc.

Thanks Pedro. perl-XML-Parser is fine now.
Still a problem with pcc and racket though.
https://github.com/openSUSE/brp-check-suse/pull/29 helped with pcc reproducibility in my tests.

There is a new racket version 7.4: https://racket-lang.org/
You can ask the maitainers to update the package. The osc maintainer command returns: toganm, KGronlund, olszewst
May I ask you why do the packages distribute *.o files in RPM?
That's the runtime startup code of the PCC compiler. It's purpose is similar to the crt*.o files distributed by gcc packages.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-14444: binutils: apply_relocations in readelf.c in GNU Binutils 2.32 contains an integer overflow that allows attackers to trigger a write access violation (in byte_put_little_endian function in elfcomm.c) via an ELF file

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-14444
apply_relocations in readelf.c in GNU Binutils 2.32 contains an integer overflow that allows attackers to trigger a write access violation (in byte_put_little_endian function in elfcomm.c) via an ELF file, as demonstrated by readelf.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-14444 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-14444 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24829
Created attachment 812275 CVE-2019-14444-binutils.patch

binutils is affected in the following code streams:
SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update SUSE:SLE-12-SP5:Update SUSE:SLE-12:Update SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update SUSE:SLE-15:Update

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-1010204: binutils: out-of-bounds read in elfcpp/elfcpp_file.h

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-1010204
GNU binutils gold gold v1.11-v1.16 (GNU binutils v2.21-v2.31.1) is affected by: Improper Input Validation, Signed/Unsigned Comparison, Out-of-bounds Read. The impact is: Denial of service. The component is: gold/fileread.cc:497, elfcpp/elfcpp_file.h:644. The attack vector is: An ELF file with an invalid e_shoff header field must be opened.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-1010204 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-1010204 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23765

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-12972: binutils: heap-based buffer over-read in _bfd_doprnt in bfd.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-12972
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.32. There is a heap-based buffer over-read in _bfd_doprnt in bfd.c because elf_object_p in elfcode.h mishandles an e_shstrndx section of type SHT_GROUP by omitting a trailing '\0' character.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-12972 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2019/CVE-2019-12972.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-12972 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24689 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=890f750a3b053532a4b839a2dd6243076de12031

bug.short_desc: binutils: strip lefts temporary files

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 809150 crypto.o
Hi,
I am running Leap 15.1 with binutils-2.31-lp151.2.29.x86_64
When running strip as the following (please, find crypto.o attached)
strip -p --strip-debug --discard-locals -R .comment -R .note crypto.o
I see lots of error messages (that is ok), and empty file created in the working directory st1b7FZK. The filename is always random prefixed by "st". Leaving empty files is NOT okay, even if I am feeding strip with a garbage.
You may wonder: why do you do that? Answer is simple: this issue has implications on the build process in OBS for erlang package. strip is run by brp-15-strip-debug on this file, leaving hardly avoidable empty files in the resulting RPM package. This files also have 0600 permissions, that triggers some other issues.

bug.short_desc: [Tracker] binutils: support s390x arch13 instructions

long_desc.thetext:
For fate#327074 and jsc#SLE-6206 we need either a backport of patches adding support for new z13 instructions, or an update of binutils version to at least 2.32. These new instructions are used by an updated glibc, which is also requested as feature for sle12-sp5 (fate#327072), so the binutils update is a prerequisite for this.
This bug is for the purpose of tracking that. The patches are from these commits: f47998d69f8d290564c022b010e63d5886a1fd7d S/390: Support vector alignment hints 13daa8e4889a971309f7d46a8d49129cb26088a5 S/390: Fix optional operand handling after memory addresses 126b2985ce48d879c9d829b2245e4f00d05a6a74 S/390: Implement instruction set extensions ba354106f02e25c9adc3dc1364d6a974216ec94e S/390: arch13: Add instruction descriptions 40f382e88d0391ffaa4098c92cbf339a7924a629 S/390: arch13: Adjust to recent changes This patch is a non-functional change but still desirable for sake of completeness:
As the update of the toolchain module is some time away but we want to get some free testing from the sp5 build, we go the patch route for now.
We also don't want source split between current SLE12 binutils and the SLE12-SP5 binutils (later in the summer all will be upgraded to 2.32 or 2.33 anyway). For the time being we submit binutils to SLE-12:Update and to SLE-12-SP5:GA, if the former is checked in first the latter isn't necessary anymore, if the other way around, then the sp5 variant can be removed once sle12-update is checked in.

QA REPRODUCER:
size hbo
should not crash
This has been a high severity vulnerability for some time. Any update or plans for the patch?

This is a typical script-kiddie-fuzzes CVE, not anything worth a high priority. The NIST categorization of these is notoriously non-sensical.
We fix this type of CVEs with version updates of binutils, so the next one will contain a fix.

Thanks Michael for your prompt response and explanation of the severity from SUSE's standpoint. We understand that the NIST categorization and scoring can be off sometimes, but do see that SUSE is still listing this as a High severity vulnerability on the SUSE CVE page as well (https://www.suse.com/security/cve/CVE-2019-9075/). Do you have an estimation on when the binutils update expected to be released?

bug.short_desc: crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges
bug.product: Beta SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP1

long_desc.thetext:
Microsot SQL team is running SQL TPC-E benchmark, we need to tune some kernel configuration parameters.
SLES15 version:
SPE-PURLEY-07:/usr/src # cat /etc/os-release NAME="SLES" VERSION="15-SP1" VERSION_ID="15.1" PRETTY_NAME="SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP1" ID="sles" ID_LIKE="suse" ANSI_COLOR="0;32" CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:suse:sles:15:sp1" SPE-PURLEY-07:/usr/src # uname -a Linux SPE-PURLEY-07 4.12.14-30-default #1 SMP Fri Jan 25 15:21:53 UTC 2019 (7f76697) x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
The repro is simple:
cd /usr/src/linux zcat /proc/config.gz > .config make oldconfig
we are getting the following errors:
HOSTCC scripts/basic/fixdep /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: unable to initialize decompress status for section .debug_aranges /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../lib64/crti.o: file not recognized: file format not recognized collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status make[1]: *** [scripts/Makefile.host:107: scripts/basic/fixdep] Error 1 make: *** [Makefile:471: scripts_basic] Error 2
I think the best triaging information I was able to get was this issue with the elfutils recent change and not using binutils 2.32 https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=242682
we have only binutils-2.31-6.3.1.x86_64
This archlinux forum mentions a “patched” version of binutils v2.31 with a fix or to downgrade both elfutils and libelf.
My questions: - Have you seen this issue? - If yes, do you any fix for us to execute?
Hi Michael, since it mentioned binutils, I cc you

Yes, this issue is known. But it should only be visible in inconsistent systems, not in fully updated ones. See bug#1123601, where the reporter was using a system that used packages from a SLE15 SP1 tree that was in an intermediate state of rebuilding.
This should not happen for a fully built-through tree, and certainly not in a tree that was exposed to customers.
So, please tell us the exact version of glibc-devel as well.
Just to be sure, please also provide the output of:
% rpm -q --changelog binutils | head -n 5 % rpm -q --changelog glibc-devel | head -n 5

SPE-PURLEY-07:/opt/intel # rpm -q --changelog binutils | head -n 5 * Tue Aug 28 2018 matz@suse.com - Update to binutils-2_31-branch @e51abf7e3, minor bugfixes in the support for the X86_ISA_1_* notes. Adds patch binutils-2.31-branch.diff.gz . - Add binutils-revert-plt32-in-branches.diff on anything older SPE-PURLEY-07:/opt/intel # rpm -q --changelog glibc-devel | head -n 5 * Wed Nov 07 2018 schwab@suse.de - x86-haswell-string-flags.patch: Fix Haswell CPU string flags (bsc#1114984, BZ #23709) - pthread-cond-broadcast-waiters-after-spinning.patch: Fix waiters-after-spinning case (bsc#1114993, BZ #23538)
/lib64/libc-2.26.so
Hello All, any update on this bug?

There seems to be some inconsisteny with the package versions in the various Beta trees for SLE15-SP1, that might lead to this problem.
Essentially the binutils you have (with the Aug 28 2018 entry as most recent changelog) has rpm version 2.31-6.3.1. But it definitely is an old binutils version that is not able to handle the new crti.o file from newly compiled glibc.
Am I correct in assuming that you glibc-devel package is at version 2.26-15.5 (rpm -q glibc-devel)? If so, you have a glibc from Beta3 but binutils from Beta2, and that is not going to work.
If that is true then the problem is that the rpm version of the binutils package for Beta3 is 2.31-5.2, and that is _lower_ than from Beta2. So a normal update would have updated glibc, but not binutils, leading to this problem.
You can verify this by explicitely installing the other binutils version ('zypper in binutils=2.31-5.2' - maybe you need to select something to allow downgrading package versions). If that then works it's really just a problem with the rpm versions in the product trees.
For this rpm version problem I'm CCing some people who might know the cause. For those, there is this problem:
% ll /dist/SLP/SLE-15-SP1-Module-Basesystem-Beta*/x86_64/DVD1/x86_64/binutils-2* -r--r--r-- 1 root root 5978328 Oct 16 15:35 /dist/SLP/SLE-15-SP1-Module-Basesystem-Beta2/x86_64/DVD1/x86_64/binutils-2.31-6.3.1.x86_64.rpm -r--r--r-- 1 root root 5979428 Jan 28 15:49 /dist/SLP/SLE-15-SP1-Module-Basesystem-Beta3/x86_64/DVD1/x86_64/binutils-2.31-5.2.x86_64.rpm
Note how the rpm version is lower in the beta3 tree.

Thank you Mike, it worked.
I close the bug for now.

To use the Intel processor low-level driver, we need to enable "CONFIG_UNWINDER_FRAME_POINTER" in the SLES15 kernel. By default, this one is not enabled.
I followed the following instructions.
1. zcat /proc/config.gz > .config 2. edit .config to enable CONFIG_UNWINDER_FRAME_POINTER 3. then 4. make old config && make menuconfig && make -j && make -j modules && make modules_install && make install 5. the server is rebooted.
Now the kernel is not loaded due to the signature: For info, we had disabled secure boot.
comment #7 doesn't seem to have anything to do with crti.o or glibc or binutils, or compressed debug sections. Please create a new bug report for this.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-7149: elfutils: A heap-based buffer over-read was discovered in the function read_srclines in dwarf_getsrclines.c in libdw in elfutils 0.175.

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-7149
A heap-based buffer over-read was discovered in the function read_srclines in dwarf_getsrclines.c in libdw in elfutils 0.175. A crafted input can cause segmentation faults, leading to denial-of-service, as demonstrated by eu-nm.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-7149 https://sourceware.org/ml/elfutils-devel/2019-q1/msg00068.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24102
Only Factory is affected

A fix is available at [1]. Confirmed the issue in Factory with valgrind by running eu-nm $POC
three POCs can be found in [2]
[1] https://sourceware.org/ml/elfutils-devel/2019-q1/msg00068.html [2] https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24102

This is automated batch bugzilla cleanup.
The openSUSE 42.3 changed to end-of-life (EOL [1]) status. As such it is no longer maintained, which means that it will not receive any further security or bug fix updates. As a result we are closing this bug.
If you can reproduce this bug against a currently maintained version of openSUSE (At this moment openSUSE Leap 15.1, 15.0 and Tumbleweed) please feel free to reopen this bug against that version (!you must update the "Version" component in the bug fields, do not just reopen please), or alternatively create a new ticket.
Thank you for reporting this bug and we are sorry it could not be fixed during the lifetime of the release.
[1] https://en.opensuse.org/Lifetime
factory now has 0.176, assuming fixed

bug.short_desc: The gstack command sometimes hangs

long_desc.thetext:
This has been dupicated on sles 12 sp2, sp3, and sp4.
Instructions to reproduce the issue are attached. The customer has included his proposed fix.

Customer: IBM INTERNAL SR Number: 101214776981 Bug Number: 1123234 Issue Type: [0] Normal Severity: [-100] Normal Entitlement Type: [-100] Priority Workaround: [-20] No Environment: [-20] Production Frequency: [-10] Random # of Users Affected: [-50] 251-1000 Potential Users: [-15] 251-1000 DSLA Required: true NTS Defect Priority: 685
L3:53416 is now handled by Lidong Zhong.
Robert, could you attach the steps to reproduce this problem? Thanks.

For some reason, bugzilla is not allowing me to upload this file. I will paste it here: =========
gstack command sometimes hangs.
The customer reported the problem with sles12sp2 and I recreated the same issue on sles12sp3 and sp4
The problem can be recreated on my internal sles12sp3 system and the steps to recreate is as below.
(1) run many multi-thread processes (150 processes with 3 thread in each thread group)
(2) generate a list of those multi-thread processes (ps aux |grep xxxxx> nonnativeList )
(3) run gstack command by using following shell script
# for i in $(cat nonnativeList | awk '{print $2;}')
> do
> echo =============== $i ==========================
> gstack ${i}
> sleep 10
> done
(3) gstack hangs sometime late
The gstack command resumes processing if I send a SIGCONT to one of the thread which was stopped in "ptrace_stop" function. (eg. kill -SIGCONT xxxx)
sles12s3k:~ # ps -eflL |grep 40934
0 t root 40934 1 40934 0 3 80 0 - 37409 ptrace 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 S root 40934 1 40985 0 3 80 0 - 37409 hrtime 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep

0 S root 41600 41432 41600 0 1 80 0 - 934 wait 14:35 pts/0 00:00:00 /bin/sh /usr/bin/gstack 40934
0 S root 41604 41600 41604 0 1 80 0 - 12067 sigsus 14:35 pts/0 00:00:00 gdb --quiet -nx /proc/40934/exe 40934
0 S root 41610 39443 41610 0 1 80 0 - 699 pipe_w 14:36 pts/2 00:00:00 grep --color=auto 40934
sles12s3k:~ # kill -SIGCONT 40986
sles12s3k:~ # ps -eflL |grep 40934
0 S root 40934 1 40934 0 3 80 0 - 37409 futex_ 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 S root 40934 1 40985 0 3 80 0 - 37409 system 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
1 S root 40934 1 40986 0 3 80 0 - 37409 hrtime 14:26 pts/1 00:00:00 /root/pgm/pthread-nanosleep
When the problem occurs the gstack command does not complete.
The gstack command executes a gdb command and waiting for its completion.
The gdb command is suspended in sigsuspend() like below.
(TASK status from my test result)
kernel: gdb S 0000000000674eea 0 29274 29270 0x00000000
kernel: 0000000000000001 0000000000ad2e00 00000000009930d8 0000000000000000
kernel: 0000000000000000 000000001620e898 000000001620e108 0000000037800e00
kernel: 000000001620e208 0000000000ad2e00 00000000009930d8 000000000099af00

kernel: [<0000000000679698>] system_call+0xfc/0x290
kernel: [<000003ffad439b68>] 0x3ffad439b68
The task status
Hi Michael, could you please take a look at this problem? Thanks.
Where is the proposed fix from the customer? Is there a testcase that can be used to create that many processes with threads?
Tom, can you take care of this (& upstreaming in case it is not)?

The package contains the patch fixing the problem, but the test-case (attach-slow-waitpid.exp) was stripped from the patch.
I've run attach-slow-waitpid.exp with the gdb from SLE-12SP2, confirmed it failed, and then ran it with the gdb from TEST package, and confirmed it passed.

After confirming with the customer, they were duplicating this on the following version of SLES 12 SP3: gdb-8.0.1-2.3.2.s390x
Just to answer the question from comment#12, They were using pthread-nanosleep for reproducing the failure.
The customer does have an LTSS contract. They would like a PTF for a SLES 12 SP2 for s390x system.
Thanks.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-20712: binutils: heap-based buffer over-read in function d_expression_1 in cp-demangle.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-20712
A heap-based buffer over-read exists in the function d_expression_1 in cp-demangle.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31.1. A crafted input can cause segmentation faults, leading to denial-of-service, as demonstrated by c++filt.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-20712 https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=88629 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24043

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-20673: binutils: Integer overflow in demangle_template function

long_desc.thetext:
The demangle_template function in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31.1, contains an integer overflow vulnerability (for "Create an array for saving the template argument values") that can trigger a heap-based buffer overflow, as demonstrated by nm.
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1664709 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-20673 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-20673.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-20673/ http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106454 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24039
According to upstream this file is maintained by gcc and not by binutils. I could find the affected code in all supported codestreams.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-20623: binutils: use-after-free in the error function in elfcomm.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-20623
In GNU Binutils 2.31.1, there is a use-after-free in the error function in elfcomm.c when called from the process_archive function in readelf.c via a crafted ELF file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-20623 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-20623.html http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106370 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24049

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-20651: binutils: denial of service via a NULL pointer dereference in elf_link_add_object_symbols in elflink.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-20651
A NULL pointer dereference was discovered in elf_link_add_object_symbols in elflink.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31.1. This occurs for a crafted ET_DYN with no program headers. A specially crafted ELF file allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service, as demonstrated by ld.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-20651 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-20651.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24041 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=54025d5812ff100f5f0654eb7e1ffd50f2e37f5f http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106440

Right, as demonstrated by ld remote attackers can cause a denial of service. Of course.
The is lower than none priority, but bugzilla doesn't have that.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-20657: binutils: denial of service inside the demangle_template function in cplus-dem.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-20657
The demangle_template function in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31.1, has a memory leak via a crafted string, leading to a denial of service (memory consumption), as demonstrated by cxxfilt, a related issue to CVE-2018-12698.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-20657 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-20657.html https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=88539 http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106444

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-1000876: binutils: integer overflow in bfd_get_dynamic_reloc_upper_bound,bfd_canonicalize_dynamic_reloc in objdump

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-1000876
binutils version 2.32 and earlier contains a Integer Overflow vulnerability in objdump, bfd_get_dynamic_reloc_upper_bound,bfd_canonicalize_dynamic_reloc that can result in Integer overflow trigger heap overflow. Successful exploitation allows execution of arbitrary code.. This attack appear to be exploitable via Local. This vulnerability appears to have been fixed in after commit 3a551c7a1b80fca579461774860574eabfd7f18f.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-1000876 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-1000876 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23994 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=3a551c7a1b80fca579461774860574eabfd7f18f http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106304

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-19931: binutils: heap-based buffer overflow in bfd_elf32_swap_phdr_in in elfcode.h

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-19931
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils through 2.31. There is a heap-based buffer overflow in bfd_elf32_swap_phdr_in in elfcode.h because the number of program headers is not restricted.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-19931 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-19931.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-19931
https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23942 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=5f60af5d24d181371d67534fa273dd221df20c07

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-19932: binutils: integer overflow and infinite loop caused by the IS_CONTAINED_BY_LMA

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-19932
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils through 2.31. There is an integer overflow and infinite loop caused by the IS_CONTAINED_BY_LMA macro in elf.c.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-19932 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-19932.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-19932

bug.short_desc: Debug symbols are broken with gcc 8.2.1 20181108 and ld.gold 2.31.1.20180828-2) 1.16

long_desc.thetext: magrathea:~ # rpm -q binutils binutils-2.31-2.1.x86_64 magrathea:~ # ll /usr/bin/ld lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 20 Dec 3 10:08 /usr/bin/ld -> /etc/alternatives/ld magrathea:~ # ll /etc/alternatives/ld lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 16 Jan 29 2018 /etc/alternatives/ld -> /usr/bin/ld.gold

Works for me with: % ll /etc/alternatives/ld lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 15 Dec 3 17:42 /etc/alternatives/ld -> /usr/bin/ld.bfd % rpm -q binutils gdb gcc8 binutils-2.31-2.1.x86_64 gdb-8.2-2.1.x86_64 gcc8-8.2.1+r265901-1.1.x86_64
So it's probably gold that is breaking things. Can you please confirm that ld.bfd doesn't show the problem for you either?
Yes, ld.bfd works.

The problem are the compressed debug sections. E.g. .debug_str has an alignment of 8 because it's compressed. In its decompressed state it has an alignment of 1, but somehow gold doesn't deal with this correctly.
A work-around is to not make the assembler compress debug sections via --nocompress-debug-sections, like in:
% gcc -Wa,--nocompress-debug-sections -O0 -g -ggdb xopen.c

It's https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23919 where changes to support libelfs (correct) handling of alignment in compressed sections triggered a problem in gold, which then was fixed a little later as well.
I'll update binutils for tumbleweed and leap15.
This is still broken in Tumbleweed!
Yes, it fell through the cracks over christmas, so thanks for reminding.
Forget that, I confused myself, I merely missed to actually submit the package to factory. Now done.
(Oh, and sle15/leap15 doesn't need this, because the broken patch never landed there).

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-17985: binutils: stack consumption problem caused by the cplus_demangle_type

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-17985
An issue was discovered in cp-demangle.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. There is a stack consumption problem caused by the cplus_demangle_type function making recursive calls to itself in certain scenarios involving many 'P' characters.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-17985 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-17985.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-17985/ https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=87335
reproducer does not work and upstream does not seem convinced it is an issue. Monitoring upstream to see if there is any progress.
upstream fix now available: https://gcc.gnu.org/viewcvs/gcc?view=revision&revision=266886

Created attachment 796601 QA Reproducer
$ ulimit -s 2048 && c++filt -t < POC-t Segmentation fault (core dumped)

Assume these codestreams as affected: - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update - SUSE:SLE-12:Update - SUSE:SLE-15:Update
Not affected because the code seems to be missing: - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update

We've got a question from a customer why our CVSSv3 score has AV:N (attack vector network), while NIST NVD has AV:L (local); Strangely, the NVD CVSSv2 also has AV:N. I think AV:L is correct, how can this be exploited remotely?

(In reply to Joerg Reuter from comment #14) > We've got a question from a customer why our CVSSv3 score has AV:N (attack > vector network), while NIST NVD has AV:L (local); Strangely, the NVD CVSSv2 > also has AV:N. I think AV:L is correct, how can this be exploited remotely?
I don't see how it can be exploited remotely unless you go long ways like causing a crash in a remotely accessible program plus somehow arranging that a symbol in the backtrace of that crash involves a malicious symbol (by somehow overwriting the symbol table), have systemd-coredump running and core dumps enabled and systemd-coredump doing the backtrace which I believe demangles symbols (now you have to research which copy of the demangler systemd uses here - I think it one from elfutils which probably uses libiberty as well).
So yeah, AV:L (local) looks correct here.
And of course systemd inspecting random coredumps is a security issue ;) Hopefully it does this in fully isolated sandboxes. Heh.

bug.short_desc: gnatmake broken when gcc-PIE is installed

long_desc.thetext:
Consider this test-case: ... $ cat hello.adb with Ada.Text_IO;
procedure Hello is begin Ada.Text_IO.Put_Line("Hello, world!"); end Hello; ...
We're able to compile this using gnatmake: ... $ rm -f hello.ali hello.o hello ; gnatmake -v hello.adb -largs -v
GNATMAKE 8.2.1 20180831 [gcc-8-branch revision 264010] Copyright (C) 1992-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. "hello.ali" being checked ... -> "hello.ali" missing. gcc -c hello.adb End of compilation gnatbind -x hello.ali gnatlink hello.ali -v
GNATLINK 8.2.1 20180831 [gcc-8-branch revision 264010] Copyright (C) 1995-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. gcc -c -gnatA -gnatWb -gnatiw -gnatws /root/b~hello.adb /usr/bin/gcc b~hello.o ./hello.o -o hello -L./ -L/usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/ /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a -ldl -static-libgcc ...
And then run it: ... $ ./hello Hello, world! ...
However, when we install gcc-PIE: ... $ sudo zypper install gcc-PIE ...
we get a gnatlink error instead: ... $ rm -f hello.ali hello.o hello ; gnatmake -v hello.adb -largs -v
GNATMAKE 8.2.1 20180831 [gcc-8-branch revision 264010] Copyright (C) 1992-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. "hello.ali" being checked ... -> "hello.ali" missing. gcc -c hello.adb End of compilation gnatbind -x hello.ali gnatlink hello.ali -v
GNATLINK 8.2.1 20180831 [gcc-8-branch revision 264010] Copyright (C) 1995-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. gcc -c -gnatA -gnatWb -gnatiw -gnatws /root/b~hello.adb /usr/bin/gcc b~hello.o ./hello.o -o hello -L./ -L/usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/ /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a -ldl -static-libgcc /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(a-contai.o): relocation R_X86_64_32 against symbol `ada__containers__capacity_error' can not be used when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(a-except.o): relocation R_X86_64_32S against `.rodata' can not be used when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(a-finali.o): relocation R_X86_64_32S against symbol `ada__finalization__controlledT' can not be used when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(a-chahan.o): relocation R_X86_64_32S against symbol `ada__characters__handling__char_map' can not be used when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(a-elchha.o): relocation R_X86_64_32S against symbol `system__soft_links__task_termination_nt' can not be used when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(s-exctra.o): relocation R_X86_64_32 against `.text' can not be used when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(s-addima.o): relocation R_X86_64_32S against `.rodata' can not be used when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: final link failed: nonrepresentable section on output collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status gnatlink: error when calling /usr/bin/gcc gnatmake: *** link failed. $ ...
The compilation fails because gnatlink uses /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a instead of /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat_pic.a.

Workaround: use -lgnat_pic: ... $ rm -f hello.ali hello.o hello ; gnatmake -v hello.adb -largs -v -lgnat_pic
GNATMAKE 8.2.1 20181025 [gcc-8-branch revision 265488] Copyright (C) 1992-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. "hello.ali" being checked ... -> "hello.ali" missing. gcc -c hello.adb End of compilation gnatbind -x hello.ali gnatlink hello.ali -v -lgnat_pic
GNATLINK 8.2.1 20181025 [gcc-8-branch revision 265488] Copyright (C) 1995-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. gcc -c -gnatA -gnatWb -gnatiw -gnatws /root/b~hello.adb /usr/bin/gcc b~hello.o ./hello.o -lgnat_pic -o hello -L./ -L/usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/ /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a -ldl -static-libgcc $ ./hello Hello, world! $ ...

We have a similar problem when gcc-PIE is not installed, and we try to build a PIE passing -pie -fPIE explicitly: ... $ rm -f hello.ali hello.o hello ; gnatmake -fPIE -v hello.adb -largs -v -pie
GNATMAKE 8.2.1 20181025 [gcc-8-branch revision 265488] Copyright (C) 1992-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. "hello.ali" being checked ... -> "hello.ali" missing. gcc -c -fPIE hello.adb End of compilation gnatbind -x hello.ali gnatlink hello.ali -fPIE -v -pie
GNATLINK 8.2.1 20181025 [gcc-8-branch revision 265488] Copyright (C) 1995-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. gcc -c -fPIE -gnatA -gnatWb -gnatiw -gnatws /root/b~hello.adb /usr/bin/gcc b~hello.o ./hello.o -fPIE -pie -o hello -L./ -L/usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/ /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a -ldl -static-libgcc /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(a-contai.o): relocation R_X86_64_32 against symbol `ada__containers__capacity_error' can not be used when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC ... /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/../../../../x86_64-suse-linux/bin/ld: final link failed: nonrepresentable section on output collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status gnatlink: error when calling /usr/bin/gcc gnatmake: *** link failed. $ ...
Note that passing -pie as toplevel option to gnatmake seems to work: ... delia:~ # rm -f hello.ali hello.o hello ; gnatmake -pie -fPIE -v hello.adb -largs -v
GNATMAKE 8.2.1 20181025 [gcc-8-branch revision 265488] Copyright (C) 1992-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. "hello.ali" being checked ... -> "hello.ali" missing. gcc -c -pie -fPIE hello.adb End of compilation gnatbind -x hello.ali gnatlink hello.ali -fPIE -v
GNATLINK 8.2.1 20181025 [gcc-8-branch revision 265488] Copyright (C) 1995-2018, Free Software Foundation, Inc. gcc -c -fPIE -gnatA -gnatWb -gnatiw -gnatws /root/b~hello.adb /usr/bin/gcc b~hello.o ./hello.o -fPIE -o hello -L./ -L/usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/ /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a -ldl -static-libgcc ... but actually the linkeline missing -pie, so we're not actually generating a PIE.

The solution for the compilation error with gcc-PIE not installed is to teach gnatlink to include libgnat_pic.a for -pie.
Assuming that's fixed, the solution for the compilation error with gcc-PIE installed could be to have a libgnat_default.a symlink, which points to: - libgnat.a, when gcc-PIE is not installed - libgnat_pic.a, when gcc-PIE is installed.
Then update gnatlink to use libgnat_default.a by default, and libgnat.a for -no-pie.

(In reply to Tom de Vries from comment #3) > The solution for the compilation error with gcc-PIE not installed is to > teach gnatlink to include libgnat_pic.a for -pie. >
Filed upstream PR87936 - "gnatlink fails with -pie" ( https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=87936 ).

I just realized there's possibly another related problem. With gcc-PIE setting the gcc default to use -fPIE -pie, libgnat is build with -fPIE (and libgnat_pic.a with -fpic).
Filed PR87938 - libgnat.a not compiled with -fno-PIC ( https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=87938 ).

(In reply to Tom de Vries from comment #5) > I just realized there's possibly another related problem. With gcc-PIE > setting the gcc default to use -fPIE -pie, libgnat is build with -fPIE (and > libgnat_pic.a with -fpic). >
Hmm, that may not be true. Building the target libraries will probably be done without taking the gcc-PIE setting into account.
> Filed PR87938 - libgnat.a not compiled with -fno-PIC ( > https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=87938 ).
Still, I think this is valid.

(In reply to Tom de Vries from comment #0) > However, when we install gcc-PIE: > ... > $ sudo zypper install gcc-PIE > ... > > we get a gnatlink error instead: > ... > $ rm -f hello.ali hello.o hello ; gnatmake -v hello.adb -largs -v ... > /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a(a-contai.o): relocation > R_X86_64_32 against symbol `ada__containers__capacity_error' can not be used > when making a PIE object; recompile with -fPIC > ... > > The compilation fails because gnatlink uses > /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat.a instead of > /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/8/adalib/libgnat_pic.a.
I've checked in ubuntu 18.04, which has PIE as default. There we still got libgnat.a and libgnat_pic.a, but libgnat.a was compiled with the default (i.e., -fPIE). So, gnatmake still selects libgnat.a, but that's not a problem.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18605: binutils: A heap-based buffer over-read issue was discovered in the function sec_merge_hash_lookup causing a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18605 A heap-based buffer over-read issue was discovered in the function sec_merge_hash_lookup in merge.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31, because _bfd_add_merge_section mishandles section merges when size is not a multiple of entsize. A specially crafted ELF allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service, as demonstrated by ld.
upstream patch: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff;h=ab419ddbb2cdd17ca83618990f2cacf904ce1d61;hp=8e3152af14a91df65af8e922a0e8e77c60ed99ba
upstream ticket: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23804
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18605 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-18605.html

Hi Michael, again the provided patch suggests that all codestreams are affected: - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata/binutils - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update/binutils

Created attachment 787127 QA reproducer (2)
$ ld -E POC2 segfaults, again verified in a openSUSE Leap 15.0 container

Created attachment 787128 QA reproducer (1)
$ ld -E POC1
reproducer segfaults, verified in openSUSE Leap 15.0 container

Why is this a security bug? It's a problem in the link editor with invalid input, how do you propose this to become relevant from a security p.o.v.? I.e. it's even less relevant than random bugs in binutils that can be observed by calling nm or similar tools for forensic analysis.
Hence, I'm not going to backport anything for this.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18606: binutils: NULL pointer dereference in _bfd_add_merge_section when attempting to merge sections with large alignments, causing denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18606 An issue was discovered in the merge_strings function in merge.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. There is a NULL pointer dereference in _bfd_add_merge_section when attempting to merge sections with large alignments. A specially crafted ELF allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service, as demonstrated by ld.
upstream patch: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff;h=45a0eaf77022963d639d6d19871dbab7b79703fc;hp=102def4da826b3d9e169741421e5e67e8731909a
upstream ticket: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23806
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18606 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-18606.html

Hi Michael, reviewing the provided patch suggests again that all codestreams are affected: - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata/binutils - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update/binutils

$ ld -E POC_ldSEGV2
reproducer segfaults, verified in openSUSE Leap 15.0 container

Why is this a security bug? It's a problem in the link editor with invalid input, how do you propose this to become relevant from a security p.o.v.? I.e. it's even less relevant than random bugs in binutils that can be observed by calling nm or similar tools for forensic analysis.
Hence, I'm not going to backport anything for this.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18607: binutils: NULL pointer dereference in elf_link_input_bfd when used for finding STT_TLS symbols without any TLS section, causing denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18607 An issue was discovered in elf_link_input_bfd in elflink.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. There is a NULL pointer dereference in elf_link_input_bfd when used for finding STT_TLS symbols without any TLS section. A specially crafted ELF allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service, as demonstrated by ld.
upstream patch: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff;h=102def4da826b3d9e169741421e5e67e8731909a;hp=ab419ddbb2cdd17ca83618990f2cacf904ce1d61
upstream ticket: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23805
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18607 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-18607.html

Created attachment 787123 QA reproducer
$ ld -E POC_ldSEGV1
Segfaults, verified in openSUSE Leap 15.0 container

Hi Michael, reviewing the code and the provided patch my understanding is that all codestreams are affected: - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata/binutils - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update/binutils

Why is this a security bug? It's a problem in the link editor with invalid input, how do you propose this to become relevant from a security p.o.v.? I.e. it's even less relevant than random bugs in binutils that can be observed by calling nm or similar tools for forensic analysis.
Hence, I'm not going to backport anything for this.

bug.short_desc: dynamic linker relocates absolute symbols in executables linked with -pie

long_desc.thetext: This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1112570) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/176388 SLE-15-SP1 / glibc
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1112570) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/180553 SLE-15 / glibc
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1112570) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/186224 SLE-15 / glibc

Hello, I'm testing the update (qam-sle) on misanthrope, a SLES 15 refhost. I get the following results, and I'm not sure whether or not the patch is working as expected (I'd say no):
misanthrope:~ # ./reproducer.good start=0x601048 end=0x601088 size=0x40
misanthrope:~ # ./reproducer.bad start=0x55b6696c9048 end=0x55b6696c9088 size=0x55b6694c8040
Size should be 0x40 in both cases, so the patch doesn't seem to work as expected for the -pie case.
x86_64: does not work aarch64: it works ppc64le: does not work
The linker is emitting a RELATIVE relocation against the symbol. So this needs additional support from the linker.
@Andreas I guess I can reject S:M:9959:185968 right?
Why?
Because the RR reports that this issue is fixed while it's not. Or am I missing something??
It needs more support from the linker, but otherwise it is fixed.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18483: binutils: The get_count function provided by libiberty allows attackers to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impact

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18483 The get_count function in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (malloc called with the result of an integer-overflowing calculation) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted string, as demonstrated by c++filt.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18483 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-18483/

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18484: binutils: Stack Exhaustion in the C++ demangling functions provided by libiberty, caused by recursive stack frames

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18484 An issue was discovered in cp-demangle.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. Stack Exhaustion occurs in the C++ demangling functions provided by libiberty, and there is a stack consumption problem caused by recursive stack frames: cplus_demangle_type, d_bare_function_type, d_function_type.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18484 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-18484/

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18309: binutils: An invalid memory address dereference was discovered in read_reloc in reloc.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18309: An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. An invalid memory address dereference was discovered in read_reloc in reloc.c. The vulnerability causes a segmentation fault and application crash, which leads to denial of service, as demonstrated by objdump, because of missing _bfd_clear_contents bounds checking.
upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=patch;h=0930cb3021b8078b34cf216e79eb8608d017864f;hp=2bf2bf23da5237f465fdbb759657aeb7825a08a3
upstream ticket: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23770
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18309 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-18309.html

Hi Michael, my investigation suggests the following about the different codestreams.
affected: - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils
probably affected, but code differs: - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata/binutils
probably _not_ affected, but wanted to confirm - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update/binutils

Created attachment 786141 QA reproducer
$ objdump -xg -W POC_SEGV (could not reproduce the issue in my setup)

bug.short_desc: Out of date package: openSUSE:Factory/binutils

long_desc.thetext: https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/openSUSE:Factory/binutils is at 2.31. Current upstream is ftp://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/binutils/binutils-2.31.1.tar.gz.

bug.short_desc: gdb does not build reproducibly

long_desc.thetext:
most content in /usr/share/doc/packages/gdb-testresults differs for every build. I guess it should be split into a separate build like with gcc8-testresults or using the (still ugly) _multibuild feature in OBS, like glibc
Another approach could be to not package the testresults at all and just print them into the build log or into another side artifact.

Can you explain "other side artifact"? Is that a new OBS feature we can use to make the testresults accessible?
IMHO we want the ability to mark a sub-package "volatile" as to not trigger rebuilds of packages depending on it -- but nothing should depend on gdb-testresults so why exactly is that not reproducing an issue at all?

https://build.opensuse.org/package/binaries/openSUSE:Factory/gdb/standard already has '_buildenv' and 'rpmlint.log' as side-artifacts for download which do not influence pkg-diff calculation.
Not sure, if/how it is possible to make these in a build.
A "volatile" flag for subpackages could also help, because I think, currently all of gdb always gets republished and there are packages that BuildRequire gdb, which could create cycles.
> grep '^BuildRequires.*gdb$' */*.spec|cut -d/ -f1 |sort -u 389-ds cimple coreutils coreutils-testsuite crda cross-*-gcc7 gcc7 gcc7-testresults gcc8 glibc go1.* installation-images ldc libqt5-creator nemiver python-qt5 verilator

(In reply to Bernhard Wiedemann from comment #2) > https://build.opensuse.org/package/binaries/openSUSE:Factory/gdb/standard > already has '_buildenv' and 'rpmlint.log' as side-artifacts for download > which do not influence pkg-diff calculation. > > Not sure, if/how it is possible to make these in a build.
And make them "nicely" downloadable from the UI. Maybe we generally can add a _testresults "stream" a package build could store a tar archieve to for example?
> A "volatile" flag for subpackages could also help, > because I think, currently all of gdb always gets republished > and there are packages that BuildRequire gdb, which could create cycles. > > > grep '^BuildRequires.*gdb$' */*.spec|cut -d/ -f1 |sort -u > 389-ds > cimple > coreutils > coreutils-testsuite > crda > cross-*-gcc7 > gcc7 > gcc7-testresults > gcc8 > glibc > go1.* > installation-images > ldc > libqt5-creator > nemiver > python-qt5 > verilator
Awww, so re-building gets decided on whether _any_ of the sub-packages of the source package of a dependency changed? Ugh...
So a "volatile" package should then not being depend on.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-17360: binutils: heap-based buffer over-read in bfd_getl32 in libbfd.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-17360
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. a heap-based buffer over-read in bfd_getl32 in libbfd.c allows an attacker to cause a denial of service through a crafted PE file. This vulnerability can be triggered by the executable objdump.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-17360 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23685

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2018-17359: binutils: invalid memory access exists in bfd_zalloc in opncls.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-17359
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. An invalid memory access exists in bfd_zalloc in opncls.c. Attackers could leverage this vulnerability to cause a denial of service (application crash) via a crafted ELF file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-17359

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2018-17358: binutils: invalid memory access exists in _bfd_stab_section_find_nearest_line in syms.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-17358
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. An invalid memory access exists in _bfd_stab_section_find_nearest_line in syms.c. Attackers could leverage this vulnerability to cause a denial of service (application crash) via a crafted ELF file.

bug.short_desc: gdb crashing when a core file has many program headers

long_desc.thetext:
Possible root-cause details,
Crash happened at following lines of code
x2306 phdrs = (Elf_Internal_Phdr *) alloca (phdrs_size); x >x2307 num_phdrs = bfd_get_elf_phdrs (core_bfd, phdrs); <---- crash happened here x x2308 if (num_phdrs == -1) x x2309 return 0;
In my case core_bfd->tdata.elf_obj_data->elf_header.e_phnum contained 200088, this results in phdrs_size of 12805632 (200088 * 64) that is around 12MB. This size is above the value of stack limit of 8MB ("ulimit -s" dumps 8192 on my system). So "alloca" succeeded (due to no bounds check) for allocation of 12MB and trying write to that allocated memory resulted in crash.
Following is the back-trace of crashed core ----------------------------------------------------------- (gdb) bt #0 0x000000000045337d in linux_vsyscall_range_raw (range=range@entry=0xc1df760, gdbarch=<optimized out>) at ../../gdb/linux-tdep.c:2307 #1 0x0000000000453588 in linux_vsyscall_range (gdbarch=<optimized out>, range=0x7fffcbf76db0) at ../../gdb/linux-tdep.c:2381 #2 0x0000000000451595 in add_vsyscall_page (target=<optimized out>, from_tty=<optimized out>) at ../../gdb/symfile-mem.c:203 #3 0x00000000006a79c5 in generic_observer_notify (args=0x7fffcbf76e00, subject=<optimized out>) at ../../gdb/observer.c:167 #4 observer_notify_inferior_created (objfile=objfile@entry=0xf03ee0 <core_ops>, from_tty=from_tty@entry=1) at ./observer.inc:426 #5 0x000000000066e1d1 in post_create_inferior (target=target@entry=0xf03ee0 <core_ops>, from_tty=from_tty@entry=1) at ../../gdb/infcmd.c:477 #6 0x00000000005f294d in core_open (arg=<optimized out>, from_tty=1) at ../../gdb/corelow.c:465 #7 0x0000000000692a18 in exec_or_core_file_attach (filename=0x7fffcbf77577 "core.reprodce_gdb_cr.12743", from_tty=1) at ../../gdb/main.c:481 #8 0x0000000000692ab8 in catch_command_errors_const (command=0x692980 <exec_or_core_file_attach(char const*, int)>, arg=arg@entry=0x7fffcbf77577 "core.reprodce_gdb_cr.12743", from_tty=1) at ../../gdb/main.c:404 #9 0x0000000000693b2b in captured_main_1 (python_script=<synthetic pointer>: <optimized out>, context=0x7fffcbf77080, this=<optimized out>) at ../../gdb/main.c:1115 #10 captured_main (data=0x7fffcbf77080) at ../../gdb/main.c:1227 #11 gdb_main (args=args@entry=0x7fffcbf77080) at ../../gdb/main.c:1257 #12 0x0000000000411691 in main (argc=2, argv=0x7fffcbf77198) at ../../gdb/gdb.c:40 -----------------------------------------------------------

There's a simple workaround - raise your stacklimit, for example by doing
> ulimit -s unlimited
Tom - can you raise/fix the issue upstream?
[I'm not sure if our RLIMIT_STACK default of 8MB is a sensible way to increase the default thread stack size on the system given it's side-effect on non-threaded programs]

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #3) > There's a simple workaround - raise your stacklimit, for example by doing > > > ulimit -s unlimited > > Tom - can you raise/fix the issue upstream? >
Submitted fix: https://sourceware.org/ml/gdb-patches/2018-11/msg00003.html

(In reply to Tom de Vries from comment #4) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #3) > > There's a simple workaround - raise your stacklimit, for example by doing > > > > > ulimit -s unlimited > > > > Tom - can you raise/fix the issue upstream? > > > > Submitted fix: https://sourceware.org/ml/gdb-patches/2018-11/msg00003.html
Committed: https://sourceware.org/ml/gdb-cvs/2018-11/msg00022.html .

bug.short_desc: SLES 15 - Transactional execution builtin (__builtin_tbegin_retry) requires -march=zEC12 (binutils)

long_desc.thetext:
== Comment: #0 - Andreas Krebbel <Andreas.Krebbel@de.ibm.com> - 2018-07-19 04:18:19 == The transactional execution builtin __builtin_tbegin_retry uses the ppa instruction which was not flagged as htm (hardware transactional memory) in Binutils. Hence the GNU assembler complained about this instruction not being available with just -mhtm option but without -march=zEC12.
The SLES 15 GCC by default builds with -march=z196. Just adding -mhtm should be enough to enable the builtins. The intention is to make the builtins available in code which does its own runtime checking for the availability of transactional execution instructions.
The problem can easily circumvented by passing -Wa,-march=zEC12 to GCC. This makes gas to accept all zEC12 instructions without making GCC emitting zEC12 instructions itself.
The problem has been fixed in upstream Binutils. The patch should be picked up for the next Binutils update in Sles 15.
https://sourceware.org/ml/binutils/2018-07/msg00312.html
*** Bug 1101824 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Andreas: can you please push that patch also to the binutils-2_31-branch branch? Probably that's the next binutils we're going to update to with the toolchain update later this year, and so we'd pick it up automatically.

------- Comment From Andreas.Krebbel@de.ibm.com 2018-07-24 07:07 EDT------- (In reply to comment #5) > Andreas: can you please push that patch also to the binutils-2_31-branch > branch? > Probably that's the next binutils we're going to update to with the toolchain > update later this year, and so we'd pick it up automatically.
Ok. Done.
------- Comment From Andreas.Krebbel@de.ibm.com 2019-09-19 04:30 EDT------- The requested patch is part of binutils-2.31-branch.diff in binutils-2.31-6.3.1.src.rpm

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2018-12699: binutils: finish_stab in stabs.c in GNU Binutils 2.30 allows attackers to cause a denialof service (heap-based buffer overflow) or possibly have unspecified otherimpact, as demonstrated by an out-of-bounds write of

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-12699
finish_stab in stabs.c in GNU Binutils 2.30 allows attackers to cause a denial of service (heap-based buffer overflow) or possibly have unspecified other impact, as demonstrated by an out-of-bounds write of 8 bytes. This can occur during execution of objdump.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-12699 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-12699/
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/binutils/+bug/1763102 https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=85454 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23057

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-10534: binutils: out-of-bounds memory write in _bfd_XX_bfd_copy_private_bfd_data_common function in peXXigen.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-10534
The _bfd_XX_bfd_copy_private_bfd_data_common function in peXXigen.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, processes a negative Data Directory size with an unbounded loop that increases the value of (external_IMAGE_DEBUG_DIRECTORY) *edd so that the address exceeds its own memory region, resulting in an out-of-bounds memory write, as demonstrated by objcopy copying private info with _bfd_pex64_bfd_copy_private_bfd_data_common in pex64igen.c.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-10534 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23110

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-10535: binutils: output_section pointer validation issue in ignore_section_sym function in elf.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-10535
The ignore_section_sym function in elf.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, does not validate the output_section pointer in the case of a symtab entry with a "SECTION" type that has a "0" value, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (NULL pointer dereference and application crash) via a crafted file, as demonstrated by objcopy.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-10535 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23113

bug.short_desc: gdb is giving an internal-error saying to report it as a bug.

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 768461 supportconfig
Using SLES 12 SP2 with latest gdb version. (gdb-8.0.1-1.5.1.x86_64). I also had them try gdb-8.1-184.1.x86_64.rpm from https://build.opensuse.org/package/binaries/devel:gcc/gdb/SLE-12 and it showed the same problem.
Partner reported the following and asked me to report it.
From partner: I’m trying to use gdb with a C++ app that uses boost threads and it appears that after it hits a breakpoint with threads active, gdb becomes unstable and wants to quit (see attached). The text says it’s an assertion failure and “this is a bug” in gdb.
I updated the latest gdb from patchfinder (gdb-8.0.1-1.5.1.x86_64) and I’m still seeing the same result. I uploaded a supportconfig:
nts_sdac_180426_1455.tbz
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Breakpoint 3, 0x00007ffff6abea04 in pthread_create@@GLIBC_2.2.5 () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
(gdb) bt
#0 0x00007ffff6abea04 in pthread_create@@GLIBC_2.2.5 () from /lib64/libpthread.so.0
#1 0x00007ffff710c5f9 in boost::thread::start_thread_noexcept() () from /root/libboost_thread.so.1.54.0
../../gdb/gdbtypes.c:1727: internal-error: int internal_type_vptr_fieldno(type*): Assertion `TYPE_CODE (type) == TYPE_CODE_STRUCT || TYPE_CODE (type) == TYPE_CODE_UNION' failed.
A problem internal to GDB has been detected,
further debugging may prove unreliable.
Quit this debugging session? (y or n) y
This is a bug, please report it. For instructions, see:
<http://bugs.opensuse.org/>.
../../gdb/gdbtypes.c:1727: internal-error: int internal_type_vptr_fieldno(type*): Assertion `TYPE_CODE (type) == TYPE_CODE_STRUCT || TYPE_CODE (type) == TYPE_CODE_UNION' failed.
A problem internal to GDB has been detected,
further debugging may prove unreliable.
Create a core file of GDB? (y or n) y
./dbg.sh: line 27: 7876 Aborted (core dumped) cgexec -g cpuset:/ gdb --args ./acq_bench --direct --peer=viewsource{0..3} --writer view --chunk-size $((32*1024*1024/4)) --file ${filename} $(printf -- "--reader-affinity-cpus %s " $DCS_READ_TASKS_CPUS ) $(printf -- "--reader-membind-nodes %s " $DCS_VIEW_BUFFER_NODES ) $(printf -- "--writer-affinity-cpus %s " $DCS_WRITE_TASK_CPU ) $(printf -- "--writer-membind-nodes %s " $DCS_WRITE_TASK_NODE ) --buffer-chunk-count 32 --frag-count 32000 $*

From the partner: I noticed that it asks me if I want to create a core file but I never get one (even tried ulimit -c unlimited).
Fortunately, I just figured out where my application issue is without gdb, so this gdb issue isn’t blocking me right now."

Asked the partner for steps to reproduce the issue and got this reply:
"The common denominator seems to be our “libnetacq” library which is huge and contains a lot of proprietary info so I can’t share it. I’ll try to pare it down to figure out if there is something in particular that’s triggering this condition.
In gdb it seems once I do a C++ symbol lookup with tab completion that’s enough to trigger this crash. For example this sequence:
start b ‘boost:thread<tab>
In my case I was able to set a breakpoint on a C symbol, but when I tried to get a backtrace after hitting the breakpoint gdb would crash. Strangely enough though, the gstack command that comes with the gdb package never failed (I thought gstack did essentially the same thing).
I’ll get back to you if I learn anything else."

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-10372: binutils: process_cu_tu_index allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (heap-based buffer over-read and application crash)

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-10372
process_cu_tu_index in dwarf.c in GNU Binutils 2.30 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (heap-based buffer over-read and application crash) via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by readelf.
Reproducer: readelf -w bug3 doesn't work without ASAN
All codestreams affected.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-10372 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-10372.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23064

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-10373: binutils: concat_filename allows remote attackers to cause adenial of service (NULL pointer dereference)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 768353 Reproducer
CVE-2018-10373
concat_filename in dwarf2.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (NULL pointer dereference and application crash) via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by nm-new.
Reproducer doesn't trigger without ASAN.
All codestreams affected.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-10373 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-10373.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23065
