bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-9996: binutils: Stack Exhaustion in the C++ demangling functions provided by libiberty allowing for DoS

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 766723 Reproducer
CVE-2018-9996
Details in https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=85304
All codestreams affected as far as I can see, but this is really, really minor.
Reproduction: cxxfilt < poc_test
(We don't ship cxxfilt, but this is only a entrypoint to the vulnerable code)
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-9996 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-9996/

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-9138: binutils: An issue was discovered in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed inGNU Binutils 2.29 and 2.30. Stack Exhaustion occurs in the the C++demangling functions provided by libiberty, and there are recursiv

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-9138
Description
An issue was discovered in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29 and 2.30. Stack Exhaustion occurs in the the C++ demangling functions provided by libiberty, and there are recursive stack frames: demangle_nested_args, demangle_args, do_arg, and do_type.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-9138 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-9138.html

bug.short_desc: dev tools module: gdb crashes when entering TUI mode

long_desc.thetext:
when entering TUI mode GDB crashes. Let's assume we have a hello word test programm:
# gdb ./test GNU gdb (GDB; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 8.0.1 Copyright (C) 2017 Free Software Foundation, Inc. License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html> This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it. There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law. Type "show copying" and "show warranty" for details. This GDB was configured as "aarch64-suse-linux". Type "show configuration" for configuration details. For bug reporting instructions, please see: <http://bugs.opensuse.org/>. Find the GDB manual and other documentation resources online at: <http://www.gnu.org/software/gdb/documentation/>. For help, type "help". Type "apropos word" to search for commands related to "word"... Reading symbols from /root/test...done. (gdb) - Segmentation fault (core dumped) #

Created attachment 764904 coredump of gdb
Attached a coredump of the crashed gdb
Would you be so nice and try the gdb from devel:gcc (obs)? It works for me on x86_64, but just to make sure. (it's version 8.1, so newer than for SLE-15)
Works with devel:gcc version: GNU gdb (GDB; devel:gcc) 8.1
Michael, let me know if you need guidance on which machine you can test. On IRC my nick is matthias_bgg
Michael, not sure if this bug is supposed to be solved but I still get SIGSEV when entering TUI mode with the latest version of GDB shipped by SLE15:Update which is gdb-8.2-3.6.1.x86_64.
It works for me on leap 15.0. Ah, this is about SLE-15 AARCH64 ...

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-8945: binutils: The bfd_section_from_shdr function in elf.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD)library (aka libbfd) allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-8945
The bfd_section_from_shdr function in elf.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (segmentation fault) via a large attribute section.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-8945 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-8945.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-8945/ https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22809
Created attachment 764721 ELF reproducer
Created attachment 764722 PE reproducer
Created attachment 764723 Proposed upstream patch

Could not reproduce, upstream suggests that the memory allocation fails due to memory exhaustion. Attached patch should fix the big allocation.
attr support was added with commit 4b41ba5318, which first appeared in version 2.18. This makes the codestream "SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update" not affected. SLE11/SLE12 codestreams probably are and the patch should be applied.

bug.short_desc: linking i386 fails with assertion in bfd/elf.c:3564

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 764064 rombios_32bit.tar.gz
Since recently home:olh:xen-unstable/xen fails to build in Tumbleweed:
[ 329s] make[10]: Entering directory '/home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/xen-4.11.20180316T205828.0012ae8afb/non-dbg/tools/firmware/rombios/32bit' [ 330s] ld -melf_i386 -s -r 32bitbios.o tcgbios/tcgbiosext.o util.o pmm.o -o 32bitbios_all.o [ 330s] ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; openSUSE Tumbleweed) 2.30.0.20180226-2 assertion fail ../../bfd/elf.c:3564
Removing -g3 from CFLAGS fixes it. See attached testcase.
Perhaps 'zypper in xen-devel', it happens to work for me.
Created attachment 764080 rombios_32bit.tar.gz

Ok, so
ld -melf_i386 -s -r 32bitbios.bad.o -o 32bitbios_all.bad.o
is enough to reproduce this. separately stripping works for me. I guess nobody uses -s.
Using -g3 -gstrict-dwarf also makes it work.
Without -gstrict-dwarf we have
[ 1] .group GROUP 00000000 000034 00000c 04 23 15 4 [ 2] .group GROUP 00000000 000040 00000c 04 23 16 4 [13] .debug_macro PROGBITS 00000000 0000ff 0008e1 00 0 0 1 [14] .rel.debug_macro REL 00000000 00386c 000aa0 08 I 23 13 4 [15] .debug_macro PROGBITS 00000000 0009e0 000016 00 G 0 0 1 [16] .rel.debug_macro REL 00000000 00430c 000018 08 IG 23 15 4 [17] .debug_macro PROGBITS 00000000 0009f6 000052 00 G 0 0 1 [18] .rel.debug_macro REL 00000000 004324 000068 08 IG 23 17 4
COMDAT group section [ 1] `.group' [wm4.stdcpredef.h.19.3bd61da18dac034cbf4a4b99f8f2e646] contains 2 sections: [Index] Name [ 15] .debug_macro [ 16] .rel.debug_macro
COMDAT group section [ 2] `.group' [wm4.rombios_compat.h.2.d518a25213ddee794b75640ef514494a] contains 2 sections: [Index] Name [ 17] .debug_macro [ 18] .rel.debug_macro
and with there's no extra group nor any relocation for .debug_macro.
Testcase:
> echo '#define FOO BAR' > t.c > gcc-7 t.c -g3 -c > ld -r -s t.o -o tx.o ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; devel:gcc / openSUSE_Leap_42.2) 2.30.0.20180226-0 assertion fail ../../bfd/elf.c:3564 ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; devel:gcc / openSUSE_Leap_42.2) 2.30.0.20180226-0 assertion fail ../../bfd/elf.c:3564
https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22981
I suggest to stop using ld -s.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-7208: gdb,binutils: In the coff_pointerize_aux function in coffgen.c in the Binary File Descriptor(BFD) library an index is not validated, which allows remote attackers to cause DoS

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-7208
In the coff_pointerize_aux function in coffgen.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, an index is not validated, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (segmentation fault) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted file, as demonstrated by objcopy of a COFF object.
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1546622 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-7208 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-7208/ https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22741

Upstream bug: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22741 Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=eb77f6a4621795367a39cdd30957903af9dbb815
All supported codestreams are affected for both gdb as well as binutils.

bug.short_desc: gcc doesn't work when bash isn't the login shell

long_desc.thetext:
gcc fails with the below error when fish is the login shell: simon@tek-top ~/src/tmp ➤ gcc -o locale locale.c gcc: error trying to exec 'cc1': execvp: No such file or directory
if I run the same command inside bash --login it compiles fine. So at a guess we are setting some environment variables in a bash only location.
This issue is also in Leap 15, earlier versions of Leap and Tumbleweed did not have this issue.

You need to provide more information here. We don't have any GCC specific environment. Can you provide strace output of the failing command? Can you provide the environment contents of your fish login shell (and that in case of bash, just for completeness?).
Also, output of 'gcc -v -o locale locale.c'.

At a hunch that I still need to confirm, I suspect this is because fish doesn't load /etc/profile and as such environment variables like HOST CPU OSTYPE MACHTYPE aren't loaded. But I need to find some time to investigate this better.

GCC doesn't use those.
The driver as of today looks at
getenv("TERM") = "xterm" getenv("GCC_EXEC_PREFIX") = nil getenv("PATH") = "/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin" getenv("PATH") = "/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin" getenv("COMPILER_PATH") = nil getenv("LIBRARY_PATH") = nil getenv("LPATH") = nil getenv("GCC_COMPARE_DEBUG") = nil getenv("GCC_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("BINUTILS_ROOT") = nil getenv("MAKEFLAGS") = nil
the error from the driver means it cannot find cc1.
Maybe you have _bogus_ (GCC_EXEC_PREFIX?) environment with fish?

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-6323: binutils: The elf_object_p function in elfcode.h in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd) has an unsigned integer overflow because bfd_size_type multiplication is not used

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 757724 Reproducer
CVE-2018-6323
The elf_object_p function in elfcode.h in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, has an unsigned integer overflow because bfd_size_type multiplication is not used. A crafted ELF file allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact.
This problem only affects i686.
Reproducer (does not trigger on x86_64): objdump -x c2
Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=38e64b0ecc7f4ee64a02514b8d532782ac057fa2
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-6323 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22746

bug.short_desc: Libqb logging not working correctly with binutils >= 2.29 (linker ld.bfd)

long_desc.thetext:
Binutils has been updated to 2.29.1 for *all* SLE12 releases IIUC: https://build.suse.de/project/show/SUSE:Maintenance:5836
(-- I don't see any channels for SLE12-GA or SLE12-SP1 explicitly listed in here: https://maintenance.suse.de/incident/5836
But there's binutils-2.29.1-9.20.2.x86_64.rpm in SLE12:Update project: http://download.suse.de/ibs/SUSE:/SLE-12:/Update/standard/x86_64/
Please correct me if I'm wrong.)
Unfortunately binutils-2.29 introduced a change of behavior (or rather a regression) with ld.bfd linker, which affects libqb logging.
The issue was orignally brought up from: https://www.mail-archive.com/developers@clusterlabs.org/msg00459.html
, and tracked in: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1477354
Impacts: Packages that are build-time linked with libqb < 1.0.3 by using binutils >= 2.29 are impacted.
Symtoms: - The components that use libqb logging may lose log messages silently. - Tests that rely on matching of log messages may fail, such as pacemaker CTS and fencing regression tests.

The cause is the standard linker ld.bfd from binutils-2.29 *changed visibility* of the boundaries denoting (start, stop) symbols for orphaned sections, which are used by libqb logging.
The issue was actually noticed by binutils upstream too: http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/bug-binutils/2017-08/msg00195.html
And it was more or less addressed in binutils-2.29.1 according to: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21964 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=487b6440dad57440939fab7afdd84a218b612796
But meanwhile we also need the relevant commits from libqb side, which have been included in the new release libqb-1.0.3: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/266

The following packages depend on libqb and use libqb logging: pacemaker sbd corosync booth
As also suggested in: https://www.mail-archive.com/developers@clusterlabs.org/msg00533.html
, my proposal to resolve the issue:
Step 1) Submit/update libqb for the affected SLE12 releases with the relevant commits from here: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/266
-- We also need to check if it'll, or even have to, break ABI backward compatibility for the releases. If so, we'll have to rebuild all the relevant packages anyway.
Question a) Is there any way to run the build serivce's ABI checker probably locally before creating a maintenancne request?
Question b) > Binutils has been updated to 2.29.1 for *all* SLE12 releases AFAICS: > https://build.suse.de/project/show/SUSE:Maintenance:5836 Anyone knows how a maintenance request gets released for SLE12 GA and all SPs like binutils did in here IIUC? Or does it really mean that it has never been forked for any service packs so that an update for SLE12:Update will just be released to all the service packs?
Step 2) Check if there are any packages that already have been build-time linked with libqb < 1.0.3 by using binutils >= 2.29. If so, rebuild them with the newly submitted libqb.
There has been this one AFAICT: https://build.suse.de/request/show/150063
Antoine/Kistoffer, do you probably know the answers to the above questions? :) And please correct me if I'm missing anything in here.

a) I think there is a way, but I don't know it by heart. Maybe Antoine knows?
b) Again Antoine is the expert :D But my understanding is that this is only possible if it really was never forked for any SP before, always updated for GA only.

yes, this update has been pushed on all SLE12 SP, including GA. Which means that probably all ld.bfd linker could have been broken...
a) I don't think so. I think everything has to be done through the build service.
B) for major CVE udpate this is the fatest way to go, as binutils is stable and and rarely include regression. This is not the case for all packages pushed in update for SLE12:GA. GA is already out of support.
Don't you think the fastest way is to get binutils update again without the regression?

Thanks for the information Antoine and Kristoffer. (In reply to Antoine Ginies from comment #4) > Don't you think the fastest way is to get binutils update again without the > regression? Binutils-2.29.1 with the so-called "fix" has been included in the SLE12 maintenance update. But apparently the fix didn't revert ld.bfd fully back to the old behavior, which means libqb still has to use a so-called "band aid" (workaround) even with binutiils-2.29.1 anyway: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/266/commits/20246f544f74866885f4d9491f74152bd95e7786#diff-bafde5c89cb952d11f2456fac8599452

(In reply to Yan Gao from comment #5) > Thanks for the information Antoine and Kristoffer. > (In reply to Antoine Ginies from comment #4) > > Don't you think the fastest way is to get binutils update again without the > > regression? Or do you mean to revert all the relevant behavior changes of ld.bfd since binutils-2.29 for SLE12? That'd be better solution at least for HA ;)

(In reply to Yan Gao from comment #6) > > (In reply to Antoine Ginies from comment #4) > > > Don't you think the fastest way is to get binutils update again without the > > > regression? > Or do you mean to revert all the relevant behavior changes of ld.bfd since > binutils-2.29 for SLE12? That'd be better solution at least for HA ;) BTW, according to:
https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/266/commits/20246f544f74866885f4d9491f74152bd95e7786
, the relevant changes of ld.bfd introduced the regression are: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=cbd0eecf261c2447781f8c89b0d955ee66fae7e9
https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=b27685f2016c510d03ac9a64f7b04ce8efcf95c4
https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=7dba9362c172f1073487536eb137feb2da30b0ff

Hi Michael,
It appears that the fix (PR ld/21964) in binutils-2.29.1 didn't actually fully bring back the old behavior:
https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=487b6440dad57440939fab7afdd84a218b612796
The private->protected shift in the symbols visibility between 2.29 and 2.29.1 is not sufficient, as original libqb counted on public ones.
Do you think it makes sense to revert the relevant changes of ld.bfd that introduced the regression (the ones mentioned in comment#7 IIUC) , and keep the old behavior at least for the released SLE12 versions? Otherwise it would impact any further HA maintenance updates that depend on the current libqb builds.
Thanks a lot in advance for your help.

(In reply to Yan Gao from comment #8) > Hi Michael, > > It appears that the fix (PR ld/21964) in binutils-2.29.1 didn't actually > fully bring back the old behavior: > > https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git; > h=487b6440dad57440939fab7afdd84a218b612796 > > The private->protected shift in the symbols visibility between 2.29 and > 2.29.1 > is not sufficient, as original libqb counted on public ones.
You'll have to be a bit more specific. In which way is it not enough for these symbols to be protected (and hence publically visible, which is the crucial property that libqb needed at the time I looked at it last year)? I can't for the life of me figure out from https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/266/commits/20246f544f74866885f4d9491f74152bd95e7786 in which way the author of that comment thinks that the fixes in 2.29.1 are not enough. He talks about a great many things, amongst them compatibility or incompatibility of libraries and executables linked or not linked against libqb and using or not using these section markers themself.
In the end I can't see where he claims, and if so, in which way he claims, that also the 2.29.1 behaviour is still leading to failures.
So, please show me where it's still broken when things are linked with 2.29.1. Ideally with some self-contained testcase, but if must be some chroot or receipt showing problems with the packages involved.
> Do you think it makes sense to revert the relevant changes of ld.bfd that > introduced the regression (the ones mentioned in comment#7 IIUC) , and keep > the old behavior at least for the released SLE12 versions? Otherwise it > would impact any further HA maintenance updates that depend on the current > libqb builds.
That might be an option, but the least attractive one. First I want to understand why you think that the fix for this situation in 2.29.1 is not a full fix.

Thanks for your reply, Michael.
(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #9) > (In reply to Yan Gao from comment #8) > > Hi Michael, > > > > It appears that the fix (PR ld/21964) in binutils-2.29.1 didn't actually > > fully bring back the old behavior: > > > > https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git; > > h=487b6440dad57440939fab7afdd84a218b612796 > > > > The private->protected shift in the symbols visibility between 2.29 and > > 2.29.1 > > is not sufficient, as original libqb counted on public ones. > > You'll have to be a bit more specific. In which way is it not enough for > these symbols to be protected (and hence publically visible, which is the > crucial property that libqb needed at the time I looked at it last year)? Hope this thread that you started could remind you of some of the original thinking :) http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/bug-binutils/2017-08/msg00195.html
The crucial things are defined/declared in: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/blob/master/include/qb/qblog.h
The orphaned section is named __verbose: #define QB_ATTR_SECTION __verbose
The symbols are __start___verbose, __stop___verbose: #define QB_ATTR_SECTION_START QB_PP_JOIN(__start_, QB_ATTR_SECTION) #define QB_ATTR_SECTION_STOP QB_PP_JOIN(__stop_, QB_ATTR_SECTION)
The symbols are referenced and the section is registered in qb_log_init(): https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/blob/master/lib/log.c
QB_LOG_INIT_DATA() from qblog.h can be called by libqb consumers to do the relevant sanity check in advance.
I'm still trying to understand all the ideas about the public/protected/private symbols, the usage of them and the relevant clues in these code...
> I > can't for the life of me figure out from > > https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/266/commits/ > 20246f544f74866885f4d9491f74152bd95e7786 > in which way the author of that comment thinks that the fixes in 2.29.1 are > not enough. He talks about a great many things, amongst them compatibility > or > incompatibility of libraries and executables linked or not linked against > libqb > and using or not using these section markers themself. Indeed there are plenty of contexts over there. I didn't figure out a clue when reading through it either ;)
> > In the end I can't see where he claims, and if so, in which way he claims, > that > also the 2.29.1 behaviour is still leading to failures. He claimed it in here when I asked today: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/266#issuecomment-356866560
> > So, please show me where it's still broken when things are linked with > 2.29.1.
Please take a look at: home:yan_gao:branches:SUSE:SLE-12-SP3:Update:Test:Test/pacemaker
It's the same source as SUSE:SLE-12-SP3:GA/pacemaker but linked with binutils-2.29.1-9.20.2.
Almost all the binaries from pacemaker package/sub-packages use libqb-logging.
libqb0-1.0.1-2.15 is the original one from SLE12SP3 GA, which was linked with binutils-2.26.1-9.12.1:
readelf -s /usr/lib64/libqb.so.0.18.1 |grep verbose 158: 0000000000226f48 0 NOTYPE GLOBAL DEFAULT 26 __stop___verbose 236: 0000000000225990 0 NOTYPE GLOBAL DEFAULT 26 __start___verbose
For the original pacemaker-1.1.16-4.8 from SLE12SP3 GA linked with binutils-2.26.1-9.12.1:
readelf -s ./usr/lib/pacemaker/stonithd |grep verbose 163: 000000000061d6b0 0 NOTYPE GLOBAL DEFAULT 27 __start___verbose 166: 000000000061eb28 0 NOTYPE GLOBAL DEFAULT 27 __stop___verbose
However for the same pacemaker source built with the same libqb binary but linked with binutils-2.29.1-9.20.2 instead:
readelf -s /usr/lib/pacemaker/stonithd |grep verbose
-- There's not these symbols.
I not sure if I'm checking this in the correct way, but the practical impact is the components that use libqb logging lose quite some log messages silently.
> Ideally with some self-contained testcase, but if must be some chroot or > receipt showing problems with the packages involved. Not self-contained, but these tests were invented for testing this: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/blob/master/tests/functional/log_interlib.c https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/blob/master/tests/functional/log_interlib_client.c https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/blob/master/tests/functional/log_client.c
They are introduced from: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/266/commits/454610697b9790da14c6115b0dd8b9fe3754dd0f
There are some simple tests in here when this author first reported the binutils issue: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1477354

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #9) > First I want to > understand why you think that the fix for this situation in 2.29.1 is not a > full fix. Hi Matz,
libqb is used on all of the most important components of the HA product, what means that it would demand us to do a Maintenance Update of those very critical components for all HA customers. So, is there any possibility to provide the old binutils behavior and avoid this rebuild? If not, can you explain why? I need this input to discuss with my upper management how to proceed in this case.

(In reply to Diego Vinicius Akechi from comment #23)
> libqb is used on all of the most important components of the HA product, > what means that it would demand us to do a Maintenance Update of those very > critical components for all HA customers. So, is there any possibility to > provide the old binutils behavior and avoid this rebuild? If not, can you > explain why? I need this input to discuss with my upper management how to > proceed in this case.
Isn't the need for rebuild obvious? The shared libraries created with problematic binutils don't contain the right set of symbols in their symbol tables. To make them contain these symbols requires recreating the shared libs with a fix link editor (ld). It's like asking for a compiler bugfix resulting in miscompilation of a component, but then not wanting to recompile that component with the fixed compiler.
I find the reluctance to do maintenance updates of packages rather strange. After all, that's our very business, we update packages to fix bug.!

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #24) > (In reply to Diego Vinicius Akechi from comment #23) > > > libqb is used on all of the most important components of the HA product, > > what means that it would demand us to do a Maintenance Update of those very > > critical components for all HA customers. So, is there any possibility to > > provide the old binutils behavior and avoid this rebuild? If not, can you > > explain why? I need this input to discuss with my upper management how to > > proceed in this case. > > Isn't the need for rebuild obvious? The shared libraries created with > problematic binutils don't contain the right set of symbols in their symbol > tables. To make them contain these symbols requires recreating the shared > libs with a fix link editor (ld). It's like asking for a compiler bugfix > resulting > in miscompilation of a component, but then not wanting to recompile that > component with the fixed compiler. Fortunately, we haven't yet officially released any related components for SLE12 after the update of binutils. Indeed we'll have to rebuild the pending scheduled sbd maintenance update which was built with problematic binutils I believe.
What we have been expecting is that any further maintenance updates can be correctly built against the originally released libqb & components with a fixed binutils :)

Findings: 1) If sticking with the original libqb shipped by SLE12 releases which was built with binutils-2.26.1-9.12.1, rebuilt/updated libqb's consumers such as pacemaker and sbd linked with the test binutils are OK.
2) With a rebuilt/updated libqb linked with the test binutils, original pacemaker and sbd don't work
3) With a rebuilt/updated libqb linked with the test binutils, rebuilt/updated pacemaker and sbd don't work
4) By using the updated libqb WITH the workaround linker script, either original or rebuilt/updated pacemaker and sbd are OK.
AFAICT, the test binutils helps with case 1).
I didn't actually expect it'd work for case 2).
I actually was really hoping it'd work for case 3), but seems not unfortunately.
It works for case 4) of course because of the workaround in libqb.
To summarize, the test binuitls helps with case 1) which is an improvement, but it doesn't help with case 3) unfortunately.
What are your opinions, Michael?

Created attachment 767844 patch for libqb
So, FWIW, something like this patch for libqb. Fixes above problem and makes the fencing testsuite go through without FAILs. My theory why it worked before at all is that the __start___verbose symbols were not PROTECTED but DEFAULT (i.e. global), so looking up that symbol for a shared lib that didn't contain those symbols (there are many) actually found the syms from the main object. Now that they are PROTECTED that doesn't happen anymore. So the old binutils behaviour hid this bug, but now doesn't anymore.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #31) > Created attachment 767844 [details] > patch for libqb > > So, FWIW, something like this patch for libqb. Fixes above problem and makes > the fencing testsuite go through without FAILs. My theory why it worked > before > at all is that the __start___verbose symbols were not PROTECTED but DEFAULT > (i.e. global), so looking up that symbol for a shared lib that didn't contain > those symbols (there are many) actually found the syms from the main object. > Now that they are PROTECTED that doesn't happen anymore. So the old > binutils behaviour hid this bug, but now doesn't anymore. Thank you so much for the investigations and the patch!
I was assuming that "GLOBAL DEFAULT" really made differences than "GLOBAL PROTECTED", but didn't have an idea why. Now it makes sense.

AFAICS, the test binutils is good enough to be released for maintenance. What's your opinion, Michael? I'm reassigning it to you for now for tracking the submission/maintenance of binutils.
According to all the tests, I think we'll need to follow these to do maintenance of libqb and the packages that depend on it for SLE12 releases:
1) Any maintenance of libqb and the packages that depend on it should be built with the fixed binutils containing the relevant fixes back-ported from binutils.2.30.
2) We can stick with the originally released libqb. The maintenance of the packages that depend on it should be built with the fixed binutils.
3) In case that we need to do maintenance for libqb itself, we should either preferably use Michael's patch otherwise the linker script which is used in the latest libqb. The originally released packages that depend on libqb will still work.
Michael, please point out if I'm mistaken or missing anything. Thanks.

Hi Michael, yes, bintuils is fine.
OTOH, the workaround linker script and the relevant changes from libqb-1.0.3, which actually has been shipped in sle15 GA, introduced other issues like bug#1098449. So it's kind of a fragile solution and we could not ship it again for SLE12SP4.
We'll need to wait for this latest solution to be officially released by libqb upstream: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/322
, which is basically to give up maintaining callsite sections at linking time.
But before that, we have to prevent the failed scenarios mentioned in comment#27.

But comment #47 specifically says that the new binutils (2.31) makes something not work in SP4 that was working before (implying it did do work with 2.29 binutils). Now you say 2.31 binutils is fine. So who is right? Was it also not working with 2.29 binutils (in SP4), or was it?
The (unexpected) fails of comment #27 case (3) were fixed by my patch in comment #31, so maybe you haven't applied it?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #51) > But comment #47 specifically says that the new binutils (2.31) makes > something > not work in SP4 that was working before (implying it did do work with 2.29 > binutils). That was about a thoughtless libqb submission for SLE12SP4 without any form of fix/solution from its side. We dropped it now, meaning so far we've been sticking with the original sp3 libqb linked by binutils-2.26.
> Now you say 2.31 binutils is fine. So who is right? Was it also > not working with 2.29 binutils (in SP4), or was it? > > The (unexpected) fails of comment #27 case (3) were fixed by my patch in > comment > #31, so maybe you haven't applied it? No. I knew it's a proper fix (-- Appreciated that) and tried to propose it to upstream. The libqb upstream eventually goes for this way though: https://github.com/ClusterLabs/libqb/pull/322
For the long term, we'd probably better stick with the upstream.

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-17121: binutils: Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd) allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-17121
The Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory access violation) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a COFF binary in which a relocation refers to a location after the end of the to-be-relocated section.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-17121 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-17121.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-17121/ http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-17121 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=b23dc97fe237a1d9e850d7cbeee066183a00630b https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22506

Created attachment 751732 QA Reproducer
SLE12> objdump -W perform_reloc
perform_reloc: file format pei-i386
Contents of the section:
00000000 ZERO terminator
objdump: perform_reloc: warning: illegal symbol index 131072 in relocs objdump: perform_reloc: warning: illegal symbol index 0 in relocs Segmentation fault (core dumped)

Upstream fix:
https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=b23dc97fe237a1d9e850d7cbeee066183a00630b
Unfortunately not only used for reads. Please submit for SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update SUSE:SLE-12:Update Thank you
(In reply to Johannes Segitz from comment #3) ping, please submit

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-16827
The aout_get_external_symbols function in aoutx.h in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (slurp_symtab invalid free and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted ELF file.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-16829: gdb: The _bfd_elf_parse_gnu_properties function in elf-properties.c doesn't prevent negative prointers and it could lead to remote denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-16829
The _bfd_elf_parse_gnu_properties function in elf-properties.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, does not prevent negative pointers, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (out-of-bounds read and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted ELF file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-16829 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-16829.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-16829 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22307 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=cf54ebff3b7361989712fd9c0128a9b255578163
gdb uses the libbfd from binutils, which aren't affected.
gdb has it static linked but dont provide it. It is affected.

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-16831: binutils: missing validation in coffgen.c in libbfd could lead to remote denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-16831
coffgen.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, does not validate the symbol count, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (integer overflow and application crash, or excessive memory allocation) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted PE file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-16831 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-16831.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-16831 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22385 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=6cee897971d4d7cd37d2a686bb6d2aa3e759c8ca
this one is exploitable. Due to the integer overflow the allocation can be too small for the data written
please submit this one for SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update SUSE:SLE-12:Update SUSE:SLE-15:Update Thank you
(In reply to Johannes Segitz from comment #2) ping, please submit

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-16826: binutils: Invalid memory access on coff_slurp_line_table function in coffcode.h in libbfd could lead to denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-16826
The coff_slurp_line_table function in coffcode.h in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (invalid memory access and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted PE file.

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-15996: binutils: elfcomm.c in readelf allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-15996
elfcomm.c in readelf in GNU Binutils 2.29 and possible older versions, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (excessive memory allocation) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted ELF file that triggers a "buffer overflow on fuzzed archive header," related to an uninitialized variable, an improper conditional jump, and the get_archive_member_name, process_archive_index_and_symbols, and setup_archive functions.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-15996 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-15996/ http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-15996 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=d91f0b20e561e326ee91a09a76206257bde8438b https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22361

bug.short_desc: Application stalls in Unwind function

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 743560 HANA profile
When throwing multiple exceptions (50++) in parallel, our HANA development observes that HANA can become extremely slow or completely hangs for a longer time on very large systems (UV300 / 32 sockets / 48 TiB). Their analysis shows that most of the time (90%) is spent in the Unwind function, as can be seen in the attached profile.
They currently try to mitigate the problem by avoiding exceptions as much as possible, but since the problem is still there and can heavily impact productive usage, they would like to understand the situation better.
When searching the web for similar issues, we came across this thread https://lists.freebsd.org/pipermail/freebsd-threads/2008-April/004262.html
with the related (invalid) bug entry https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=36030
Although invalid at that time, the bug more or less describes our current problem. Is there something where we could jointly follow up on? The system is running a recent SLE 12 SP1 and our colleagues suspect the situation to be impacted by larger environments.
Than you very much in advance!

I think the __dl_iterate_phdr bottleneck is known (can't find a glibc bugzilla tho). Given in your case we have many readers and no writers so a multi-reader/single-writer lock would be a convenient thing to have there. I've not seen such in glibcs infrastructure tho.
CCing glibc folks.
There's pthread_rwlock_* at least, so that's sth that could be used. Of course needs to move somewhere accessible from non-threaded glibc parts.
C++ exceptions are designed to be the exception, not the rule, thus are optimized for not being taken.

See https://gcc.gnu.org/ml/gcc/2013-05/msg00253.html for a lengthy discussion about lock contention and many calls to dl_iterate_phdr.
Due to the nature of unwinding together with dlopen/dlclose facilities we can't get rid of the locks itself. The about only ideas in that mail thread are revolving around thread-local or per-unwind-local caching of information and I personally don't see any other possibilities either. Those ideas are more or less theoretic, most have deep ABI implications.
Regarding mostly-read structures (comment #1): since glibc 2.12 (i.e. long before SLE-12) dl_iterate_phdr uses a write-specific lock:
int __dl_iterate_phdr (int (*callback) (struct dl_phdr_info *info, size_t size, void *data), void *data) { struct link_map *l; struct dl_phdr_info info; int ret = 0;
/* Make sure nobody modifies the list of loaded objects. */ __rtld_lock_lock_recursive (GL(dl_load_write_lock)); __libc_cleanup_push (cancel_handler, NULL); ...
But even though this lock is specific for the write path (i.e. the dlopen/close routines take it only before modifying any of the interesting data structures), the above call simply uses __rtld_lock_lock_recursive, which, if I'm understanding the various glibc internal headers correctly, doesn't make a difference between readers and writers.
If so, then the above locking call synchronizes also between different callers of dl_iterate_phdr, without any need to do so, as this function only reads.
So, yes, this specific instance of overly blocky dl_iterate_phdr might be solvable by using proper read/write locks. Andreas, any opinion?
Libc locks are simple (recursive) mutexes, if you need finer graned locking you need to use separate locks.
There is also __libc_rwlock_t, but it lacks infrastructure to be usable from rtld.
Ah, yes, I see. Using it for the dl_load_write_lock would most probably help this specific use case quite some. Would be cool to work on getting the infrastructure in place for this.

Replacing just dl_load_write_lock with a rwlock won't help because that lock is only held when the list of loaded objects is about to be modified. This is already the minimum required extent where __dl_iterate_phdr needs to be locked out.

(In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #10) > Replacing just dl_load_write_lock with a rwlock won't help because that lock > is only held when the list of loaded objects is about to be modified. This > is already the minimum required extent where __dl_iterate_phdr needs to be > locked out.
It will help removing the lock contention on simultaneous invocations of __dl_iterate_phdr because that function only needs to take a read lock.

Just for completeness let me also mention these bugreports discussing this and related problems: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71744 (Concurrently throwing exceptions is not scalable, but not testcase just general discussion) and https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=2377 which contains a testcase involving exceptions, threads and dlopen/close (the latter being the reason for the locks).

Sorry for the flurry of comments :) From the above glibc thread which contains the testcase the author tried a hack with an rwlock and didn't see performance improvements with it (on the testcase), as also rwlocks seem to hold a lock (and not using atomics?), for a short time, but still a synchronization point.
In any case, we should try nevertheless and make SAP try that then.
I don't think dl_iterate_phdr can usefully be made to run in parallel without fixing the cache usage in the libgcc unwinder.
Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #16) > Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache > either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which > gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?
Thank you Michael (and of course Andreas and Richard), this discussion already looks very promising! We are going to check what HANA version was used in the specific customer case, as the gcc/libgcc version depends on the version used, and our colleagues are trying to prepare a comparable test system. Since we are using the toolchain module, shouldn't the newest libgcc_s1-package be sufficient?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #16) > Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache > either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which > gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?
So the cache relies on an implementation detail (we never get concurrent invocations of the _Unwind_IteratePhdrCallback due to the lock in the glibc implementation). Sth that seems worth to fix anyway for correctness, like by making it thread-local or by making cache operations atomic or wrapped inside a lock (eh...). I guess the cache might not work very well with threads anyhow.
L3:49392 is now handled by Vasilis Liaskovitis.

Severity and priority are not set correctly. It's a very complicated issue and it's very old and known since a long time and occurs only when using exceptions in an arguably wrong way. It can't be major, and certainly is not of high priority. In fact there's actually no bug. It's a feature request really.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #20) > Severity and priority are not set correctly. It's a very complicated issue > and it's very old and known since a long time and occurs only when using > exceptions in an arguably wrong way. It can't be major, and certainly is > not of high priority. In fact there's actually no bug. It's a feature > request really.
OK, it seems this could be handled as a FATE then, and is outside of L3 scope. I marked this as enhancement and medium priority, but feel free to change. I will close the L3 if there are no objections.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #21) > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #20) > > OK, it seems this could be handled as a FATE then, and is outside of L3 > scope. I marked this as enhancement and medium priority, but feel free to > change. I will close the L3 if there are no objections.
It could be handled as L3-question as well, I believe. The thing is, eventually we might want to give SAP some TEST packages for them to try, which are normally built by L3; it just isn't very urgent. Would that work for you to leave L3 involved in this one?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #22) > It could be handled as L3-question as well, I believe. The thing is, > eventually we might want to give SAP some TEST packages for them to try, > which are normally built by L3; it just isn't very urgent. Would that work > for you to leave L3 involved in this one?
Sure that works, I can leave L3 open.
If you think it will take a long time (e.g. more than 4-6 weeks) to prepare TEST packages, as it is not urgent, I can also close and re-open L3 when you have the packages for them to try.
@Michael I am assigning this to you. Feel free to re-assign though.
@Michael, let me know if there is a candidate patch to be tested here - I can then build an L3 for the partner to test.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #25) > @Michael, let me know if there is a candidate patch to be tested here - I > can then build an L3 for the partner to test.
I will, but I doubt it'll happen this year.

@Michael, any chance to get a test package in the next weeks?
If a patch is not likely to happen in Q1, I 'll close the L3 and re-open it once you have a patch for testing. The bug can stay open of course.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #27) > @Michael, any chance to get a test package in the next weeks?
Pfew, I don't know. Let's be realistic and say no.
> If a patch is not likely to happen in Q1, I 'll close the L3 and re-open it > once you have a patch for testing. The bug can stay open of course.
Okay, then let's do that.

bug.short_desc: -fstack-clash-protection writes beyond array bounds

long_desc.thetext:
When allocating a zero-length array with alloca or as a VLA the code produced by -fstack-clash-protection accesses the array beyond bounds. The failure can best be seen on armv7 (or targets without their own probe_stack insn) where a stack probe is destructive, and where it breaks glibc.
https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/Base:System/glibc/openSUSE_Factory_ARM/armv7l
The C standard says that VLA shall not have zero size, but a size of 1 is valid, and the default probe_stack expansion writes to a MEM of word_mode.

So we have to surround the code generated by the final
+ if (flag_stack_clash_protection) + emit_stack_probe (target);
with a compare against zero and jump.
SLE is affected as well.

(In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #1) > The C standard says that VLA shall not have zero size, but a size of 1 is > valid, and the default probe_stack expansion writes to a MEM of word_mode.
So the question is whether we at least align the allocation to word_mode which I doubt.
GCC supports zero length arrays, but it is unclear if it also supports zero length VLA.
ldconfig on aarch64 is also affected.
Hmpf. Indeed, some hardening is in order, aligning the size to wordmode and checking for zeroness. I'm going to work on that, but the labs conf interferes a small bit.

The generated code for probing "char zero[pad]":
mov r6, sp add r3, r3, #7 bic r3, r3, #7 cmp r3, #4096 bcc .L128 .L186: sub r3, r3, #4096 sub sp, sp, #4096 cmp r3, #4096 str r0, [sp, #8] bcs .L186 .L128: ldr r7, [fp, #-56] sub sp, sp, r3 mov r1, #0 add r3, sp, #8 mov r0, r3 str r0, [sp, #8]
The offset of #8 means that it overwrites a nearby variable.

For "char *dir = strdupa (aux_cache_name);" it generates an insn with unpredictable behavior:
mov r0, r5 bl strlen(PLT) add r3, r0, #15 add r2, r0, #1 bic r3, r3, #7 cmp r3, #4096 bcc .L281 .L320: sub r3, r3, #4096 sub sp, sp, #4096 cmp r3, #4096 str r0, [sp] bcs .L320 .L281: sub sp, sp, r3 ldr r1, [fp, #-172] mov r0, sp str r0, [r0], #7 <====== bic r0, r0, #7 bl memcpy(PLT)
cache.s:2116: Warning: source register same as write-back base
The latter is filed as PR82248.
so both arm 32 and 64bit are currently broken regardng that option?
It is unknown whether other architectures are affected.

As one data point: I was comparing the testresults (GCC testsuite) of all SLE11 architectures on gcc43 with this patch, they were clean. So either the testsuite doesn't contain a problematic alloca, or only aarch64 is affected. Are we caring for arm 32 bit?
Most likely none of them is testing zero-size VLA.
My home:matz2:clash-check project made enough progress on armv7l and aarch64 that I think I've fixed the problem, so gcc7 is submitted as SR #528941 now.
Is this now better?
Looks so.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-12967: binutils: The getsym function in tekhex.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (akalibbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29, allows remote attackers to cause adenial of service (stack-based buffer over-re

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-12967
The getsym function in tekhex.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (stack-based buffer over-read and application crash) via a malformed tekhex binary.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-12967 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-12967 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-12967/ https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21962

Created attachment 737414 stack_overflow_getsym
QA REPRODUCER:
nm --target tekhex -n stack_overflow_getsym
or
objdump --target tekhex -S stack_overflow_getsym
potentially with valgrind.
On binutls 2.28 the binary is however not recognized on Factory.

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-12448: binutils: bfd_cache_close function in bfd/cache.c allows remote attackers to cause a heap use after free and possibly achieve code execution

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-12448
The bfd_cache_close function in bfd/cache.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29 and earlier, allows remote attackers to cause a heap use after free and possibly achieve code execution via a crafted nested archive file. This issue occurs because incorrect functions are called during an attempt to release memory. The issue can be addressed by better input validation in the bfd_generic_archive_p function in bfd/archive.c.
Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=patch;h=909e4e716c4d77e33357bbe9bc902bfaf2e1af24
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-12448 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-12448.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21787

Created attachment 735464 Reproducer
#> objdump -x use-after-free In archive test123: In nested archive : In nested archive : objdump: 0x2ffff00-0xffffff: File truncated objdump: 0x3c617220-0x20202020: File truncated objdump: 0x20600a3c-0x62696761: File truncated Segmentation fault (core dumped)

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-12459: binutils: bfd_mach_o_read_symtab_strtab function in bfd/mach-o.c allows remote attackers to cause an out of bounds heap write and possibly achieve code execution

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-12459
The bfd_mach_o_read_symtab_strtab function in bfd/mach-o.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29 and earlier, allows remote attackers to cause an out of bounds heap write and possibly achieve code execution via a crafted mach-o file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-12459 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-12459.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-12459/
Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=patch;h=8bdf0be19d2777565a8b1c88347f65d6a4b8c5fc

Created attachment 735450 Reproducer
#> objdump -x oob_write_mach_o_cache
oob_write_mach_o_cache: file format mach-o-le oob_write_mach_o_cache architecture: aarch64, flags 0x00000010: HAS_SYMS start address 0x0000000000000000
objdump: bfd_mach_o_canonicalize_symtab: unable to load symbols Sections: Idx Name Size VMA LMA File off Algn SYMBOL TABLE: no symbols
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
not in the 2017 toolchain submission.
so this is one of the issues that remain and we would like to fix. We currently track this for SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update Can you please submit there? Thank you
(In reply to Johannes Segitz from comment #6) ping, please have a look

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9955: binutils: DoS in get_build_id function in opncls.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9955
The get_build_id function in opncls.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (heap-based buffer over-read and application crash) via a crafted file in which a certain size field is larger than a corresponding data field, as demonstrated by mishandling within the objdump program.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9955 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-9955/ https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21665
Created attachment 730319 CVE-2017-9955.poc1
Created attachment 730320 CVE-2017-9955.poc2

I've was only able to run the reproducer on Tumbleweed. SLE didn't come up with any valgrind errors.
The second reproducer file didn't produce any error even on Tumbleweed.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9755: binutils: DoS in opcodes/i386-dis.c that does not consider the number of registers for bnd mode

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9755
opcodes/i386-dis.c in GNU Binutils 2.28 does not consider the number of registers for bnd mode, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (buffer overflow and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by mishandling of this file during "objdump -D" execution.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9755 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9755 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21594

Reproducer output is a bit inconclusive.
#> valgrind objdump -D testcase.cve-2017-9755 ... ... ==3362== ERROR SUMMARY: 10000000 errors from 2 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0)
Upstream Fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=0d96e4df4812c3bad77c229dfef47a9bc115ac12
Low prio, not remotely exploitable.
This is an autogenerated message for OBS integration: This bug (1044925) was mentioned in https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/533970 Factory / binutils

hi The SLES11SP3-LTSS was affected by this CVE-2017-9755, but the new package for SLES11SP3 LTSS have not yet released. so please release the new package for sles11sp3 ltss as soon.
thanks
Requires social engineering and looks hard to exploit since you can only indirectly influence what will be copied with stpcpy

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9750: binutils: DoS in opcodes/rx-decode.opc lacks bounds checks for certain scale arrays

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9750
opcodes/rx-decode.opc in GNU Binutils 2.28 lacks bounds checks for certain scale arrays, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (buffer overflow and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by mishandling of this file during "objdump -D" execution.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9750 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9750 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21587

Reproducer from https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21587 did not work on SLE or openSUSE.
#> objdump -D testcase.cve-2017-9750
testcase.cve-2017-9750: file format elf32-little
objdump: can't disassemble for architecture UNKNOWN!
However, the affected/fixed code is present.
Upstream Fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=db5fa770268baf8cc82cf9b141d69799fd485fe2
Low prio, but yeah, we enable this architecture.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9748: binutils: DoS in ieee_object_p function in bfd/ieee.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9748
The ieee_object_p function in bfd/ieee.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, might allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (buffer overflow and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by mishandling of this file during "objdump -D" execution. NOTE: this may be related to a compiler bug.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9748 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9748 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21582

Reproducer from https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21582 is not working in SLE or openSUSE.
#> objdump -D testcase.cve-2017-9748 objdump: testcase.cve-2017-9748: File truncated
However, the affected/fixed code is present.
Upstream Fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=63634bb4a107877dd08b6282e28e11cfd1a1649e
Low prio typical fuzzing "CVE" from script kiddies.

bug.short_desc: [patch-lost-in-sle] Missing issues in openSUSE:Factory/gdb

long_desc.thetext:
The following issues were referenced in the changelog for SUSE:SLE-12-SP3:GA/gdb, but where not found in openSUSE:Factory/gdb after 30 days. Review the issues and submit changes to openSUSE:Factory to ensure all relevant changes end up in openSUSE:Factory which is used as the basis for the next SLE version. For more information and details on how to go about submitting the changes see https://mailman.suse.de/mlarch/SuSE/research/2017/research.2017.02/msg00051.html.
- bug#987637 owned by matz@suse.com: VUL-1: CVE-2016-6131: gdb: libiberty emangler segfaults - bug#896586 owned by rguenther@suse.com: GDB internal-error: value_of_register_lazy: Assertion `frame_id_p (get_frame_id (frame))' failed. - bug#895831 owned by rguenther@suse.com: gdbserver gets conditionals wrong on ppc64le - bug#970589 owned by rguenther@suse.com: Debuggee process is put in the background when exiting gdb on zSeries - bug#994537 owned by matz@suse.com: SLES12 SP2 - GDB source test cases fails in large numbers - bug#976404 owned by rguenther@suse.com: gdb 7.9.1-3.2 broken on SLES 11 SP1 thru SP4 on zSeries (L3:)

Review the issues and submit changes to openSUSE:Factory to ensure all relevant changes end up in openSUSE:Factory which is used as the basis for the next SLE version. For more information and details on how to go about submitting the changes see https://mailman.suse.de/mlarch/SuSE/research/2017/research.2017.02/msg00051.html.
- [bsc#970021](https://bugzilla.suse.com/show_bug.cgi?id=970021) owned by vmoutoussamy@suse.com: chrpath missing biarch/multiarch/multilib support

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9053: libdwarf: Heap-based buffer over-read in _dwarf_read_loc_expr_op()

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9053
An issue, also known as DW201703-005, was discovered in libdwarf 2017-03-21. A heap-based buffer over-read in _dwarf_read_loc_expr_op() is due to a failure to check a pointer for being in bounds (in a few places in this function).
Fixed in cc37d6917011733d776ae228af4e5d6abe9613c1
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9053 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9053

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9054: libdwarf: _dwarf_decode_s_leb128_chk() a byte pointer is dereferenced just before it was checked for being in bounds

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9054
An issue, also known as DW201703-002, was discovered in libdwarf 2017-03-21. In _dwarf_decode_s_leb128_chk() a byte pointer was dereferenced just before it was checked for being in bounds, leading to a heap-based buffer over-read.
Fixed by cc37d6917011733d776ae228af4e5d6abe9613c1 in dwarf_leb.c. We don't have the check at all.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9054 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9054

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9052, CVE-2017-9055: libdwarf: Missing bound checks in dwarf_formsdata()

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9055
An issue, also known as DW201703-001, was discovered in libdwarf 2017-03-21. In dwarf_formsdata() a few data types were not checked for being in bounds, leading to a heap-based buffer over-read.
Fixed by cc37d6917011733d776ae228af4e5d6abe9613c1 in dwarf_form.c
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9055 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9055

Also CVE-2017-9052. The new CVE system is total crap.
An issue, also known as DW201703-006, was discovered in libdwarf 2017-03-21. A heap-based buffer over-read in dwarf_formsdata() is due to a failure to check a pointer for being in bounds (in a few places in this function) and a failure in a check in dwarf_attr_list().
Same commit, can't tell which part belongs to which CVE.
*** Bug 1039693 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

AddressSanitizer can not provide additional info. SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: SEGV /tmp/portage/sys-devel/binutils-9999/work/binutils/binutils/readelf.c:16671:16 in print_symbol_for_build_attribute ==7569==ABORTING
Affected version: master at 2017-04-12 (dunno about other versions)

bug.short_desc: binutils: enable as-needed by default

long_desc.thetext:
Inside the build service environment created by /usr/bin/build, $SUSE_ASNEEDED is set and ld behaves as if it were passed -Wl,--as-needed. Outside that box, in a "normal" system, SUSE_ASNEEDED=0. This behavior is puzzling to some people every now and then. https://lists.opensuse.org/opensuse-packaging/2017-05/msg00000.html
I think we should always enable --as-needed for the openSUSE "normal" system.
Debian systems also behave such that an incorrect -l order leads to builds stopping.
Yeah, initially we didn't want this because there was much code in the wild that got it wrong. That time has long gone, so I agree. I'll do the change with next binutils update.
But do we really want to deviate from upstream here?

Well, we already deviate in half of Geeko land. The first maxime is therefore to make it behave equal again across SUSE products. Secondarily is to have a look at what other distros do, and evaluate whether to go with the not-upstream-default behavior. Besides Debian, it would appear that Gentoo also has as-needed enabled. as-needed is one of many strategies to drop unnecessary dependencies and to also find programming errors due to effects of link order sensitiviy (missing libs, etc.). I anecdotally remember solaris ld being link-order-sensitive (but not as-needy) too, so that's that.
In other words, it just helps me and others make somewhat better software.
Actually we can propose to make that change upstream as well, then we wouldn't deviate :-)

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-8398: binutils: heap buffer overflow in printf_common (dwarf.c)

Ref: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-8398 =================================================== Description
dwarf.c in GNU Binutils 2.28 is vulnerable to an invalid read of size 1 during dumping of debug information from a corrupt binary. bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-8393: binutils: libbfd: global-buffer-overflow in objcopy (SHT_REL/SHR_RELA sections)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 723325 21412_upstream_crash_info
Ref: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-8393 =================================================== Description
The Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, is vulnerable to a global buffer over-read error because of an assumption made by code that runs for objcopy and strip, that SHT_REL/SHR_RELA sections are always named starting with a .rel/.rela prefix. This vulnerability causes programs that conduct an analysis of binary programs using the libbfd library, such as objcopy and strip, to crash. ===================================================

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-7614: binutils: elflink.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd) NULL pointer undefined behavior could lead to denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-7614
elflink.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, has a "member access within null pointer" undefined behavior issue, which might allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via an "int main() {return 0;}" program.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-7614 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-7614/ http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-7614 https://blogs.gentoo.org/ago/2017/04/05/binutils-two-null-pointer-dereference-in-elflink-c/
note that it is not a NULL ptr deref, but a potential one under preconditions.

Yikes, that's a whole new class of pseudo-CVEs. This isn't even about fuzzing, but about using a undefined-behaviour checker (i.e. for checking of strict C language constraints) on some sources. In practice this specific type of undefined behaviour (an '&x->member' construct with x potentially NULL) is handled naturally by all compilers and poses no actual problem. This can't possibly trigger any segfault.
And of course let's all ignore the fact that elflink.c is only used by the linker and hence isn't exposed remotely (even less likely than something like readelf where it's already borderline if it even deserves CVEs).
The only reason why I don't close this a WONTFIX is because Nick was so nice to cobble up a patch already.

Of course the idea would be that bh would be dereferenced later.
_bfd_generic_link_add_one_symbol() in 2.28 catches bh being NULL (The if (*hashp==NULL)) checks.)
As much as I appreciate finding and fixing bugs, this one seems not have needed a CVE as there seems to be no impact.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-7227: binutils: GNU linker (ld) in GNU Binutils 2.28 is vulnerable to a heap-based bufferoverflow

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-7227
GNU linker (ld) in GNU Binutils 2.28 is vulnerable to a heap-based buffer overflow while processing a bogus input script, leading to a program crash. This relates to lack of '\0' termination of a name field in ldlex.l.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-7227 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-7227 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-7227/ https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=20906

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2014-9939: binutils: ihex.c in GNU Binutils < 2.26 stack buffer overflow

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2014-9939
ihex.c in GNU Binutils before 2.26 contains a stack buffer overflow when printing bad bytes in Intel Hex objects.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2014-9939 http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2015/07/31/6 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-9939 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=7e27a9d5f22f9f7ead11738b1546d0b5c737266b https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=18750

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-6965: binutils: readelf in GNU Binutils heap-based buffer overflow

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-6965
readelf in GNU Binutils 2.28 writes to illegal addresses while processing corrupt input files containing symbol-difference relocations, leading to a heap-based buffer overflow.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-6965 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-6965 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21137
Blaeh, useless automatic fuzzer finds. Fixed in devel:gcc, as well as a collection of other sec fixes as well.

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2016-9275:
Description: https://blogs.gentoo.org/ago/2016/11/07/libdwarf-heap-based-buffer-overflow-in-_dwarf_skim_forms-dwarf_macro5-c Reproducer: https://github.com/asarubbo/poc/blob/master/00027-libdwarf-heapoverflow-_dwarf_skim_forms
CVE-2016-9276: Description: https://blogs.gentoo.org/ago/2016/11/07/libdwarf-heap-based-buffer-overflow-in-dwarf_get_aranges_list-dwarf_arange-c Reproducer: https://github.com/asarubbo/poc/blob/master/00026-libdwarf-heapoverflow-dwarf_get_aranges_list
Fix for both is in https://sourceforge.net/p/libdwarf/code/ci/583f8834083b5ef834c497f5b47797e16101a9a6/
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2016-9275 http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q4/403 http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q4/401 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2016/CVE-2016-9275.html
bugbot adjusting priority

bug.short_desc: gdb build often stalls on OBS

long_desc.thetext:
gdb is among the list of packages that often cause a stall in OBS - OBS detects this after a while and cancels the build.
The issue though is that unreliable builds are a pain and must not happen (especially when being a ring package; it is built very often in the stagings and every fail requires the staging managers to interact)
The current fail I have here stops with:
<[ 6299s] Running target unix/-m32/-fPIC/-pie >[ 6299s] Using /usr/share/dejagnu/baseboards/unix.exp as board description file for target. >[ 6299s] Using /usr/share/dejagnu/config/unix.exp as generic interface file for target. >[ 6299s] Using /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/gdb/testsuite/config/unix.exp as tool-and-target-specific interface file. >[ 6299s] Running /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/gdb/testsuite/gdb.xml/tdesc-arch.exp ... >[ 6299s] /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/build-x86_64-suse-linux/gdb/gdb version 7.11.1 -nw -nx -data-directory /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/build-x86_64-suse-linux/gdb/testsuite.unix.-m32.-fPIC.-pie/../data-directory >[ 6299s] >[ 6299s] >[ 6299s] === gdb Summary === >[ 6299s] >[ 6299s] # of expected passes 8 >[ 6300s] /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/build-x86_64-suse-linux/gdb/gdb version 7.11.1 -nw -nx -data-directory /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/build-x86_64-suse-linux/gdb/testsuite.unix.-m32.-fPIC.-pie/../data-directory >[ 6300s] >[35104s] ### WATCHDOG MARKER END ### >[35104s] No buildstatus set, either the base system is broken (kernel/initrd/udev/glibc/bash/perl) >[35104s] or the build host has a kernel or hardware problem... > > >Job seems to be stuck here, killed. (after 28800 seconds of inactivity)
It would be interesting to recover the buildroot given there are detailled logfiles of the testsuite run ...

Yes indeed. I don't see how I can debug this otherwise as it's not reproducable locally (or at least I seem to be unable to).
I've seen this in the past as well, and I suspect some interaction between the qemu virtualization OBS uses and the specific hw features that gdb uses.
If you have some statistics: is there anything in common on all buildhosts where it stops making progress in difference to those where it finishes?

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2016-8680: libdwarf: heap-based buffer overflow in _dwarf_get_abbrev_for_code (dwarf_util.c)

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2016-8680. Reported by Agostino Sarubbo
https://blogs.gentoo.org/ago/2016/10/04/libdwarf-heap-based-buffer-overflow-in-_dwarf_get_abbrev_for_code-dwarf_util-c/
AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow ... READ of size 1 libdwarf/dwarf_util.c:624:43 in _dwarf_get_abbrev_for_code
